title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: It is a pleasure and an honor to speak here today at the 60th Annual Meeting of the National Association for Business Economics (NABE).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Since 1959, NABE has promoted the use of economics in the workplace and advanced the worthy purpose of ensuring that leading American businesses benefit from the insights of economists.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Today I will focus on the Federal Reserve's ongoing efforts to promote maximum employment and stable prices.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: I am pleased to say that, by these measures, the economy looks very good.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The unemployment rate stands at 3.9 percent, near a 20-year low.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Inflation is currently running near the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) objective of 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: While these two top-line statistics do not always present an accurate picture of overall economic conditions, a wide range of data on jobs and prices supports a positive view.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In addition, many forecasters are predicting that these favorable conditions are likely to continue.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: For example, the medians of the most recent projections from FOMC participants and the Survey of Professional Forecasters, as well as the most recent Congressional Budget Office (CBO) forecast, all have the unemployment rate remaining below 4 percent through the end of 2020, with inflation staying very near 2 percent over the same period.1

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: From the standpoint of our dual mandate, this is a remarkably positive outlook.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Indeed, I was asked at last week's press conference whether these forecasts are too good to be true--a reasonable question!

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Since 1950, the U.S. economy has experienced periods of low, stable inflation and periods of very low unemployment, but never both for such an extended time as is seen in these forecasts.2Standard economic thinking has long offered an explanation for this: If unemployment were to remain this low for this long, employers would be pushing up wages as they compete for scarce workers, and rising labor costs would feed into more‑rapid price inflation faced by consumers.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: This dynamic between unemployment and inflation is known as a Phillips curve relationship, and at times it can pose a fundamental tension between the two sides of the Fed's mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Recent low inflation and unemployment have some analysts asking, "Is the Phillips curve dead?

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: "3Others argue that the Phillips curve still lurks in the background and could reemerge at any time to exact revenge for low unemployment in the form of high inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: My comments today have two main objectives.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The first is to explain how changes in the Phillips curve help account for the somewhat surprising but broadly shared current forecasts of continued very low unemployment with inflation near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: At the risk of spoiling the surprise, I do not see it as likely that the Phillips curve is dead, or that it will soon exact revenge.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: What is more likely, in my view, is that many factors, including better conduct of monetary policy over the past few decades, have greatly reduced, but not eliminated, the effects that tight labor markets have on inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: However, no one fully understands the nature of these changes or the role they play in the current context.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Common sense suggests we should beware when forecasts predict events seldom before observed in the economy.4

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Thus, my second objective today is to explain, given this uncertainty about the unemployment-inflation relationship, the important role that risk management plays in setting monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: I will explore the FOMC's monitoring and balancing of risks as well as our contingency planning for cases when risk becomes reality.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Historical Perspective on Jobs and InflationLet us start with a look at the modern history of jobs and inflation in the United States.Figure 1shows headline inflation and unemployment from 1960 to today and extended through 2020 using the average of median projections from both FOMC participants and the Survey of Professional Forecasters, and the CBO projections.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As the figure makes clear, a multiyear period with unemployment below 4 percent and stable inflation would, if realized, be unique in modern U.S. data.5

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To understand the basis for these forecasts, it is useful to contrast two very different periods included in figure 1: From 1960 to 1985, and the period from 1995 to today.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The first period includes the Great Inflation, and the latter includes both the Great Moderation and the distinctly immoderate period of the Global Financial Crisis and its aftermath.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Figure 2shows unemployment and core, rather than headline, inflation in these two periods.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: While our inflation objective concerns headline inflation, switching to core inflation makes some relationships clearer by removing a good deal of variability due to food and energy prices, variability that is not primarily driven by labor market conditions or monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: There is a dramatic difference in the unemployment-inflation relationship across these two periods.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: During the Great Inflation, unemployment fluctuated between roughly 4 percent and 10 percent, and inflation moved over a similar range.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In the recent period, the unemployment rate also fluctuated between roughly 4 percent and 10 percent, but inflation has been relatively tame, averaging 1.7 percent and never declining below 1 percent or rising to 2.5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Even during the financial crisis, core inflation barely budged.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As a thought experiment, look at the right panel and imagine that you could see only the red line (inflation), and not the blue line (unemployment).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Nothing in the red line hints at a major economic event, let alone the immense upheaval around the time of the global financial crisis.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Notice that, in each period, there is only one episode in which unemployment drops below 4 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In the late 1960s, unemployment remained at or below 4 percent for four years, and during that time inflation rose steadily from under 2 percent to almost 5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: By contrast, the late 1990s episode of below-4-percent unemployment was quite brief, and during the episode and surrounding quarters inflation was reasonably stable and remained below 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To explore the Phillips curve relationship in these two periods more closely, we need to bring in the concept of the natural rate of unemployment.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In standard economic thinking, an unemployment rate above the natural rate indicates slack in the labor market and tends to be associated with downward pressure on inflation; unemployment below the natural rate represents a tight labor market and is associated with upward inflation pressure.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Figure 3repeats figure 2 but replaces unemployment with labor market slack as measured by unemployment minus the CBO's current estimate of the natural rate of unemployment at each point in time.6Periods of tight labor markets are shaded.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: During the Great Inflation, inflation generally rose in the tight, shaded periods and fell in the unshaded ones, just as conventional Phillips curve reasoning predicts.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: From 1995 to today, the large and persistent swings in the gap between unemployment and the natural rate were associated with, at most, a move of a few tenths in the inflation rate.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Comparing the shaded and unshaded regions, you might see some association between slack and the minor ups and downs in inflation, but the pattern is not at all consistent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: It is evidence like this that fuels speculation about the Phillips curve's demise.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Whether dead, sick, or merely resting, many of the questions about the Phillips curve come down to figuring out what changed between these two periods, and why.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Let us turn to a conceptual framework for examining these questions more systematically.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: A Simple Framework for Understanding Changes in the Jobs-Inflation RelationshipA natural starting point is the simplest form of a Phillips curve equation, which posits that inflation this year is determined by some combination of current labor market slack, inflation last year, and some other factors that I will leave aside for this discussion (figure 4):7

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The value ofBis often referred to as the slope of the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: With a larger value ofB,any change in labor market slack translates into a bigger change in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As we say, asBincreases, the Phillips curve steepens.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The value ofCdetermines inflation's persistence--that is, how long any given change in inflation tends to linger.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As the value ofCincreases, higher inflation this year translates more into higher inflation next year.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: A particularly nasty case arises whenBandCare both large.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In this case, slack has a large effect on inflation, and that effect tends to be very persistent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: One implication of a largeCis that, if a boom drives inflation up, it will tend to stay up unless offset by a subsequent bust.8

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Figure 5shows regression estimates ofBandC,computed over 20-year samples starting with the sample from 1965 to 1984 and including each 20-year sample through 2017.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: During the Great Inflation samples, the value ofCis near 1, meaning that higher inflation one year tended to translate almost one-for-one into higher inflation the next.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The Phillips curve is also relatively steep in the Great Inflation samples, with 1 extra percentage point of lower unemployment converting into roughly 1/2 percentage point of higher inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Thus, the Great Inflation presented that nasty case just described.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The estimates of bothBandCfall in value as the estimation sample shifts forward in time.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In the most recent samples, the Phillips curve is nearly flat, withBvery near zero, andCis about 0.25, meaning that roughly one fourth of any rise or fall in inflation carries forward.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: These results give numerical form to what we see in the right-hand panel of figure 3, covering the recent period: Large and persistent moves in the unemployment gap were associated with, at most, modest transitory moves in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: What Led to the Changes in the Phillips curve?These developments amount to a better world for households and businesses, which no longer experience or even fear the scourge of high and volatile inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To provide a sound basis for monetary policy, it is important to understand what happened and why, so we can avoid a return to the bad old days of the 1970s.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Like many, I believe better monetary policy has played a central role.9

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To understand the mechanism, let us ask how central banks could, presumably inadvertently, amplify and extend the duration of inflation's response to labor market tightness.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To do so, the central bank could persistentlyeasethe stance of monetary policy in response to an uptick in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: No responsible central banker today would intentionally do this, but much research suggests that during the Great Inflation, misunderstandings about how the economy worked led the Fed effectively to behave in this manner.10Some policymakers may have believed the misguided notion that accommodating permanently higher inflation could purchase permanently higher employment.11Other policymakers misperceived the level of the natural rate of unemployment, which we now believe had shifted up markedly in the 1960s.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: With the higher natural rate, the labor market was much tighter and provided much greater upward pressure on inflation than policymakers realized in real time.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As a result, they were continually "behind the curve.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The channel through which monetary policy can amplify and extend inflation's response to shocks becomes even stronger when we take account of expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: If people come to expect that upward blips in inflation will result in ongoing higher inflation, they will build that view into wage and price decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In this case, people's expectations become a force adding momentum to inflation, and breaking inflation's momentum can require convincing people to change their minds and behavior--never an easy task.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Arguably, this is why a federal funds rate near 20 percent--roughly 10 percent in real terms‑‑was required in the early 1980s to turn the tide on high inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The cost, in the form of very high unemployment, is clear in the Great Inflation figures.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The Great Inflation taught us that a main task of monetary policy is to keep inflation expectations anchored at some low level.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: This idea is behind the adoption in recent decades of inflation targets, such as the Fed's 2 percent objective, by central banks around the world.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: When monetary policy tends to offset shocks to inflation, rather than amplifying and extending them, and when people come to expect this policy response, a surprise rise or fall in labor market tightness will naturally have smaller and less persistent effects on inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Research suggests that this reasoning can account for a good deal of the change in the Phillips curve relationship.13It is also likely that many other factors have contributed to changes in inflation dynamics over recent decades.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: We do not fully understand the causes and implications of these changes, which raises risk management issues that I will take up now.14

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: A Favorable Outlook, but What Could Go Wrong?To set the stage, let us return to the situation facing the FOMC.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The baseline forecasts of most FOMC participants and a broad range of others show unemployment remaining below 4 percent for an extended period, with inflation steady near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: I have made the case that this forecast is not too good to be true and does not signal the death of the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Instead, the outlook is consistent with evidence of a very flat Phillips curve and inflation expectations anchored near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: But we still must face the cautionary advice to beware when forecasts point to rarely seen outcomes.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As a way of heeding this advice, the Committee takes a risk management approach, which has three important parts: monitoring risks; balancing risks, both upside and downside; and contingency planning for surprises.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Let me describe a few of the risks and how we are thinking about them.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Could Inflation Expectations Become Unanchored?First is the risk that inflation expectations might lose their anchor.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: We attribute a great deal of the stability of inflation in recent years to the anchoring of longer-term inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: And we are aware that it could be very costly if those expectations were to drift materially.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As you probably know from our public communications, we carefully monitor survey- and market-based proxies for expectations, and we do not see evidence of a material shift in longer-term expectations (figure 6).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The survey measures have been particularly steady for some time.15The financial market-based measures include both an expectations component and a volatile inflation premium component, so they tend to move around much more than the surveys, but we see no evidence of a material change in these measures, either.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The risks to inflation expectations are, of course, two sided.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Until this summer, inflation had remained stubbornly below 2 percent for several years.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: And major economies in much of the world have been struggling mainly with disinflationary forces.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Thus, we have been and will remain alert for possible downward drift in expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Some argue the contrary case--that by only gradually removing accommodation as the unemployment rate has fallen, the FOMC may have fallen behind the curve, thereby risking an upward drift in expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: From the standpoint of contingency planning, our course is clear: Resolutely conduct policy consistent with the FOMC's symmetric 2 percent inflation objective, and stand ready to act with authority if expectations drift materially up or down.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Could Inflation Pressures Move up More than Expected in a Hot Economy?A second risk is that labor market tightness or tightness in other parts of the production chain might lead to higher inflation pressure than expected--the "revenge of the Phillips curve" scenario.16As I mentioned, the FOMC carefully monitors a wide array of early indicators of inflation pressure to evaluate this risk.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Wages and compensation data are one important source of information.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: These measures have picked up some recently, but in a way that is quite welcome.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Specifically, the rise in wages is broadly consistent with observed rates of price inflation and labor productivity growth and therefore does not point to an overheating labor market.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Further, higher wage growth alone need not be inflationary.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The late 1990s episode of low unemployment saw wages rise faster than inflation plus productivity growth without an appreciable rise in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Despite what shows up in the aggregate wage and compensation data, however, I am sure that, like us, many of you are hearing widespread anecdotes about labor shortages and increasing bottlenecks in production.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: For example, as shown infigure 7, the words "shortage" and "bottleneck" are increasingly appearing in the Beige Book, the Federal Reserve's report summarizing discussions with our business contacts around the country.17The message we are hearing in our conversations is supported by a wide range of more conventional measures.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: For example, the survey of members of the National Federation of Independent Business finds firms increasingly reporting that job openings are hard to fill (figure 8).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Further, these businesses now list "quality of labor" as their most important problem, as opposed to the more typical report of "poor sales."

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: We review a wide variety of measures of this type, and these indicators show what I think most business people see: an economy operating with limited slack.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Notice, however, that these measures are near levels that prevailed in the late 1990s or early 2000s, a period when core inflation remained under 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: While the late 1990s case proves that elevated values of these tightness measures do not automatically translate into rising inflation, a single episode provides only limited reassurance.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Thus, the FOMC takes seriously the possibility that tight markets for labor or other inputs could provide greater upward pressure on inflation than in the baseline outlook.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Our best estimates, however, suggest that so long as inflation expectations remain anchored, a modest steepening of the Phillips curve would be unlikely to cause a significant rise in inflation or demand a disruptive policy tightening.18Once again, the key is the anchored expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Is the Natural Rate of Unemployment Lower Than Expected?A third risk--in this case an upside risk--is that the natural rate of unemployment could be even lower than current estimates.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Some have argued that the Fed should be removing policy accommodation much more slowly, pushing the economy to see if the natural rate of unemployment is lower still.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Advocates of this view note that over the past several years of policy normalization, the economy has continued to strengthen and unemployment has fallen, but inflation has remained quiet.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: As I discussed in a recent speech, many analysts have accounted for the lack of rising inflation pressure by lowering their estimate of the natural rate.19For example, since the start of 2016, the unemployment rate has fallen about 1 percentage point, and estimates of the natural rate from four well-known sources have fallen over that period between 0.3 percent and 0.7 percent (figure 9).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: If the natural rate is now materially lower than we believe, that would imply less upward pressure on inflation--the flip side of the "revenge of the Phillips curve" risk.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Our policy of gradual interest rate normalization represents the FOMC's attempt to take both of these risks seriously.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Removing accommodation too quickly could needlessly foreshorten the expansion.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Moving too slowly could risk rising inflation and inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Our path of gradually removing accommodation, while closely monitoring the economy, is designed to balance these risks.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In wrapping up this discussion of risks to the favorable outlook, I should emphasize that I have chosen to focus on three risks that are all associated with the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: There are, of course, myriad other risks.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: To name just a few, we must consider the strength of economies abroad, the effects of ongoing trade disputes, and financial stability issues.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: I hope my discussion of three particular risks gives a sense of how we approach these issues.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: ConclusionMany of us have been looking back recently on the decade that has passed since the depths of the financial crisis.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: In light of that experience, I am glad to be able to stand here and say that the economy is strong, unemployment is near 50-year lows, and inflation is roughly at our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: The baseline outlook of forecasters inside and outside the Fed is for more of the same.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: This historically rare pairing of steady, low inflation and very low unemployment is testament to the fact that we remain in extraordinary times.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
text: Our ongoing policy of gradual interest rate normalization reflects our efforts to balance the inevitable risks that come with extraordinary times, so as to extend the current expansion, while maintaining maximum employment and low and stable inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Fifteen years ago, during the period now referred to as the Great Moderation, the topic of this symposium was "Adapting to a Changing Economy."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In opening the proceedings, then-Chairman Alan Greenspan famously declared that "uncertainty is not just an important feature of the monetary policy landscape; it is the defining characteristic of that landscape.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: "1On the doorstep of the period now referred to as the Global Financial Crisis, surely few, if any, at that symposium would have imagined how shockingly different the next 15 years would be from the 15 years that preceded it.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Over the course of a long recovery, the U.S. economy has strengthened substantially.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The unemployment rate has declined steadily for almost nine years and, at 3.9 percent, is now near a 20-year low.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Most people who want jobs can find them.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Inflation has moved up and is now near the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) objective of 2 percent after running generally below that level for six years.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With solid household and business confidence, healthy levels of job creation, rising incomes, and fiscal stimulus arriving, there is good reason to expect that this strong performance will continue.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As the economy has strengthened, the FOMC has gradually raised the federal funds rate from its crisis-era low near zero toward more normal levels.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: We are also allowing our securities holdings--assets acquired to support the economy during the deep recession and the long recovery--to decline gradually as these securities are paid off.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: I will explain today why the Committee's consensus view is that this gradual process of normalization remains appropriate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As always, there are risk factors abroad and at home that, in time, could demand a different policy response, but today I will step back from these.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In keeping with the spirit of this year's symposium topic--the changing structures of the economy--I would also note briefly that the U.S. economy faces a number of longer-term structural challenges that are mostly beyond the reach of monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: For example, real wages, particularly for medium- and low-income workers, have grown quite slowly in recent decades.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Economic mobility in the United States has declined and is now lower than in most other advanced economies.2Addressing the federal budget deficit, which has long been on an unsustainable path, becomes increasingly important as a larger share of the population retires.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Finally, it is difficult to say when or whether the economy will break out of its low-productivity mode of the past decade or more, as it must if incomes are to rise meaningfully over time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: My FOMC colleagues and I believe that we can best support progress on these longer-term issues by pursuing the Federal Reserve's mandate and supporting continued economic growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The topic of managing uncertainty in policymaking remains particularly salient.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: I will focus today on one of the many facets of uncertainty discussed at the 2003 symposium--uncertainty around the location of important macroeconomic variables such as the natural rate of unemployment.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: A good place to start is with two opposing questions that regularly arise in discussions of monetary policy both inside and outside the Fed:

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With the unemployment rate well below estimates of its longer-term normal level, why isn't the FOMC tightening monetary policy more sharply to head off overheating and inflation?

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With no clear sign of an inflation problem, why is the FOMC tightening policy at all, at the risk of choking off job growth and continued expansion?

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These questions strike me as representing the two errors that the Committee is always seeking to avoid as expansions continue--moving too fast and needlessly shortening the expansion, versus moving too slowly and risking a destabilizing overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As I will discuss, the job of avoiding these errors is made challenging today because the economy has been changing in ways that are difficult to detect and measure in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: I will first lay out a standard view of a handful of basic relationships that are thought to reflect key aspects of the underlying structure of the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: I will then use that framework to explain the role that structural change plays in our current policy deliberations, focusing on how that role has been shaped by two historical episodes.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Conventional Views of Macroeconomic StructureIn conventional models of the economy, major economic quantities such as inflation, unemployment, and the growth rate of gross domestic product (GDP) fluctuate around values that are considered "normal," or "natural," or "desired."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The FOMC has chosen a 2 percent inflation objective as one of these desired values.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The other values are not directly observed, nor can they be chosen by anyone.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Instead, these values result from myriad interactions throughout the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In the FOMC's quarterly Summary of Economic Projections (SEP), participants state their individual views on the longer-run normal values for the growth rate of GDP, the unemployment rate, and the federal funds rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These fundamental structural features of the economy are also known by more familiar names such as the "natural rate of unemployment" and "potential output growth."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The longer-run federal funds rate minus long-run inflation is the "neutral real interest rate."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: At the Fed and elsewhere, analysts talk about these values so often that they have acquired shorthand names.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: For example, u* (pronounced "u star") is the natural rate of unemployment, r* ("r star") is the neutral real rate of interest, and Π* ("pi star") is the inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: According to the conventional thinking, policymakers should navigate by these stars.3In that sense, they are very much akin to celestial stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: For example, the famous Taylor rule calls for setting the federal funds rate based on where inflation and unemployment stand in relation to the stars.4If inflation is higher than Π*, raise the real federal funds rate relative to r*.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The higher real interest rate will, through various channels, tend to moderate spending by businesses and households, which will reduce upward pressure on prices and wages as the economy cools off.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In contrast, if the unemployment rate is above u*, lower the real federal funds rate relative to r*, which will stimulate spending and raise employment.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Navigating by the stars can sound straightforward.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Guiding policy by the stars in practice, however, has been quite challenging of late because our best assessments of the location of the stars have been changing significantly.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Shifting Stars during NormalizationIn December 2013, the FOMC began winding down the final crisis-era asset purchase program.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Asset purchases declined to zero over 2014, and in December 2015, the FOMC began the gradual normalization of interest rates that continues to this day.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As normalization has proceeded, FOMC participants and many other private- and public-sector analysts regularly adjusted their assessments of the stars (figure 1).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Many projections of the natural rate of unemployment fell roughly 1 full percentage point, as did assessments of the neutral interest rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Estimates of the potential growth rate of GDP slipped about 1/2 percentage point.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These changing assessments have big implications.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: For example, the 1 percentage point fall in the neutral interest rate implies that the federal funds rate was considerably closer to its longer-run normal and, hence, that policy was less accommodative than thought at the beginning of normalization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The 1 percentage point fall in the natural rate of unemployment implies at present that about 1.6 million more people would have jobs when unemployment is at its longer-run level.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These shifts in the stars generally reflect analysts' attempts to square their estimates with arriving macroeconomic data.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: For example, as the unemployment rate fell toward, and then below, estimates of its natural rate, many expected inflation to move up.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: When inflation instead moved sideways, a reasonable inference was that the natural rate was lower than previously thought.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Further, over this period, GDP growth was slower than one might have expected based on the rapid decline in unemployment and the well-known relationship between output and unemployment known as Okun's law.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Put another way, labor productivity growth consistently disappointed, which raised the question of whether that shortfall was temporary‑‑perhaps due to headwinds from the crisis--or was part of a new normal.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These assessments of the values of the stars are imprecise and subject to further revision.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: To return to the nautical metaphor, the FOMC has been navigating between the shoals of overheating and premature tightening with only a hazy view of what seem to be shifting navigational guides.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Our approach to this challenge has been shaped by two much discussed historical episodes--the Great Inflation of the 1960s and 1970s and the "new economy" period of the late 1990s.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Shifting Stars and the Great InflationWhile the crisis and its aftermath have been extraordinary in many ways, the shifting of the stars is not one of them.Figure 2illustrates the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) current estimate of movements in the natural rate of unemployment and potential GDP growth from 1960 to 2000.5Viewed against the ups and downs observed over these four decades, the recent shifts in longer-run values are not all that dramatic.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Of course, these CBO estimates benefit from many years of hindsight, whereas monetary policy must be based on assessments made in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The Great Inflation period vividly illustrates the difficulties this difference raises.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Around 1965, the United States entered a period of high and volatile inflation that ended with inflation in double digits in the early 1980s.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Multiple factors, including monetary policy errors, contributed to the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Many researchers have concluded that a key mistake was that monetary policymakers placed too much emphasis on imprecise--and, as it turns out, overly optimistic--real-time estimates of the natural rate of unemployment.6

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Figure 3compares the CBO's current view of the natural rate of unemployment in that era with an estimate by Athanasios Orphanides and John Williams of the rate as policymakers perceived it in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: From 1965 to the early 1980s, this real-time estimate of u* was well below where hindsight now places it.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The unemployment rate over this period was generally well above the real-time natural rate, and contemporary documents reveal that policymakers were wary of pushing the unemployment rate even further above u* (figure 4, top panel).7With the benefit of hindsight, we now think that, except for a few years in the mid-1970s, the labor market was tight and contributing to inflation's rise (figure 4, lower panel).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: It is now clear that the FOMC had placed too much emphasis on its imprecise estimates of u* and too little emphasis on evidence of rising inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The Great Inflation did, however, prompt an "expectations revolution" in macroeconomic thinking, with one overwhelmingly important lesson for monetary policymakers: Anchoring longer-term inflation expectations is a vital precondition for reaching all other monetary policy goals.8

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: When longer-term inflation expectations are anchored, unanticipated developments may push inflation up or down, but people expect that inflation will return fairly promptly to the desired value.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: This is the key insight at the heart of the widespread adoption of inflation targeting by central banks in the wake of the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Anchored expectations give a central bank greater flexibility to stabilize both unemployment and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: When a central bank acts to stimulate the economy to bring down unemployment, inflation might push above the bank's inflation target.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With expectations anchored, people expect the central bank to pursue policies that bring inflation back down, and longer-term inflation expectations do not rise.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Thus, policy can be a bit more accommodative than if policymakers had to offset a rise in longer-term expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Shifting Stars and the "New Economy" of the Late 1990sThe second half of the 1990s confronted policymakers with a situation that was in some ways the flipside of that in the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In mid-1996, the unemployment rate was below the natural rate as perceived in real time, and many FOMC participants and others were forecasting growth above the economy's potential.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Sentiment was building on the FOMC to raise the federal funds rate to head off the risk of rising inflation.9But Chairman Greenspan had a hunch that the United States was experiencing the wonders of a "new economy" in which improved productivity growth would allow faster output growth and lower unemployment, without serious inflation risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Greenspan argued that the FOMC should hold off on rate increases.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Over the next two years, thanks to his considerable fortitude, Greenspan prevailed, and the FOMC raised the federal funds rate only once from mid-1996 through late 1998.10Starting in 1996, the economy boomed and the unemployment rate fell, but, contrary to conventional wisdom at the time, inflation fell.11

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Once again, shifting stars help explain the performance of inflation, which many had seen as a puzzle.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Whereas during the Great Inflation period the real-time natural rate of unemployment had been well below our current-day assessment, in the new-economy period, this relation was reversed (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The labor market looked to be tight and getting tighter in real time, but in retrospect, we estimate that there was slack in the labor market in 1996 and early 1997, and the labor market only tightened appreciably through 1998 (figure 4).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Greenspan was also right that the potential growth rate had shifted up.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With hindsight, we recognize today that higher potential growth could accommodate the very strong growth that actually materialized, let alone the moderate growth policymakers were forecasting.12

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The FOMC thus avoided the Great-Inflation-era mistake of overemphasizing imprecise estimates of the stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Under Chairman Greenspan's leadership, the Committee converged on a risk-management strategy that can be distilled into a simple request: Let's wait one more meeting; if there are clearer signs of inflation, we will commence tightening.13Meeting after meeting, the Committee held off on rate increases while believing that signs of rising inflation would soon appear.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: And meeting after meeting, inflation gradually declined.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In retrospect, it may seem odd that it took great fortitude to defend "let's wait one more meeting," given that inflation was low and falling.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Conventional wisdom at the time, however, still urged policymakers to respond preemptively to inflation risk--even when that risk was gleaned mainly from hazy, real-time assessments of the stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: With the experience in the new-economy period, policymakers were beginning to appreciate that, with inflation expectations much better anchored than before, there was a smaller risk that an inflation uptick under Greenspan's "wait and see" approach would become a significant problem.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Risk Management in the Face of Shifting StarsGiven what the economy has shown us over the past 15 years, the need for the sort of risk‑management approach that originated in the new-economy era is clearer than ever before.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: That approach continues to evolve based on experience and the growing literature on monetary policy and structural uncertainty.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Experience has revealed two realities about the relation between inflation and unemployment, and these bear directly on the two questions I started with.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: First, the stars are sometimes far from where we perceive them to be.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In particular, we now know that the level of the unemployment rate relative to our real-time estimate of u* will sometimes be a misleading indicator of the state of the economy or of future inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Second, the reverse also seems to be true: Inflation may no longer be the first or best indicator of a tight labor market and rising pressures on resource utilization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Part of the reason inflation sends a weaker signal is undoubtedly the achievement of anchored inflation expectations and the related flattening of the Phillips curve.14Whatever the cause, in the run-up to the past two recessions, destabilizing excesses appeared mainly in financial markets rather than in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Thus, risk management suggests looking beyond inflation for signs of excesses.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: These two realities present challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The literature on uncertainty reviewed at the 2003 symposium--and much refined since then--provides important advice for how policy should respond, although not yet, in my view, an explicit recipe or rule that a prudent central bank should follow.15The literature on robust rules, such as so-called difference rules, for example, supports the idea of putting less emphasis on the level of unemployment relative to u*.16The FOMC's practice of looking at a broad range of indicators when assessing the state of the labor market has explicitly been part of the FOMC's Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy since its inception in 2012.17We have greatly expanded the scope of our surveillance for signs of labor market tightness and of destabilizing excesses more generally.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The risks from misperceiving the stars also now play a prominent role in the FOMC's deliberations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: A paper by Federal Reserve Board staff is a recent example of a range of research that helps FOMC participants visualize and manage these risks.18The research reports simulations of the economic outcomes that might result under various policy rules and policymaker misperceptions about the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: One general finding is that no single, simple approach to monetary policy is likely to be appropriate across a broad range of plausible scenarios.19More concretely, simulations like these inform our risk management by assessing the likelihood that misperception would lead to adverse outcomes, such as inflation falling below zero or rising above 5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Finally, the literature on structural uncertainty suggests some broader insights.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: This literature started with the work of William Brainard and the well-known Brainard principle, which recommends that when you are uncertain about the effects of your actions, you should move conservatively.20In other words, when unsure of the potency of a medicine, start with a somewhat smaller dose.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As Brainard made clear, this is not a universal truth, and recent research highlights two particularly important cases in which doing too little comes with higher costs than doing too much.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The first case is when attempting to avoid severely adverse events such as a financial crisis or an extended period with interest rates at the effective lower bound.21In such situations, the famous words "We will do whatever it takes" will likely be more effective than "We will take cautious steps toward doing whatever it takes."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The second case is when inflation expectations threaten to become unanchored.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: If expectations were to begin to drift, the reality or expectation of a weak initial response could exacerbate the problem.22I am confident that the FOMC would resolutely "do whatever it takes" should inflation expectations drift materially up or down or should crisis again threaten.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: In addition, a decade of regulatory reforms and private-sector advances have greatly increased the strength and resilience of the financial system, with the aim of reducing the likelihood that the inevitable financial shocks will become crises.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The Current SituationLet me conclude by returning to the matter of navigating between the two risks I identified--moving too fast and needlessly shortening the expansion, versus moving too slowly and risking a destabilizing overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Readers of the minutes of FOMC meetings and other communications will know that our discussions focus keenly on the relative salience of these risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The diversity of views on the FOMC is one of the great virtues of our system.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Despite differing views on these questions and others, we have a long institutional tradition of finding common ground in coalescing around a policy stance.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: I see the current path of gradually raising interest rates as the FOMC's approach to taking seriously both of these risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: While the unemployment rate is below the Committee's estimate of the longer-run natural rate, estimates of this rate are quite uncertain.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: The same is true of estimates of the neutral interest rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: We therefore refer to many indicators when judging the degree of slack in the economy or the degree of accommodation in the current policy stance.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: We are also aware that, over time, inflation has become much less responsive to changes in resource utilization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: While inflation has recently moved up near 2 percent, we have seen no clear sign of an acceleration above 2 percent, and there does not seem to be an elevated risk of overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: This is good news, and we believe that this good news results in part from the ongoing normalization process, which has moved the stance of policy gradually closer to the FOMC's rough assessment of neutral as the expansion has continued.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: As the most recent FOMC statement indicates, if the strong growth in income and jobs continues, further gradual increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will likely be appropriate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: Inflation is near our 2 percent objective, and most people who want a job are finding one.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: My colleagues and I are carefully monitoring incoming data, and we are setting policy to do what monetary policy can do to support continued growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near 2 percent.
