title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
text: "Inflation Dynamics and Monetary Policy," speech delivered at the Philip Gamble Memorial Lecture, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, September 24.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Nine years into an expansion that has sometimes proceeded slowly, the U.S. economy is performing very well.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Growth is meaningfully above most estimates of its long-term trend--though admittedly, that trend is not as strong as we would like it to be.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: The labor market is particularly robust, with unemployment at its lowest level since April 2000.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Inflation has moved up close to our 2 percent objective, although we have yet to see it remain near that objective on a sustained basis.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Today, most Americans who want jobs can find them.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: High demand for workers should support wage growth and labor force participation--the latter a measure on which the United States now lags most other advanced economies.1A tight labor market may also lead businesses to invest more in technology and training, which should support productivity growth.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: And groups such as some racial and ethnic minorities that still have higher unemployment and lower participation rates could see increasing benefits from a tight labor market.2In short, there is a lot to like about low unemployment.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Achieving our statutory goal of maximum employment in a context of price stability and financial stability is both our responsibility and our challenge.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Earlier in the expansion, as the economy recovered, the need for highly accommodative monetary policy was clear.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: But with unemployment low and expected to decline further, inflation close to our objective, and the risks to the outlook roughly balanced, the case for continued gradual increases in the federal funds rate is strong.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Current Labor Market ConditionsAt 3.8 percent, the unemployment rate is below most estimates of its long-run level, which are now clustered in the mid-4s.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Many other labor market indicators also suggest an economy near full employment.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: To name just a few, these indicators include an elevated level of job vacancies.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: For the first time since the Labor Department began collecting the data in 2000, there are now more job vacancies than there are people counted as unemployed.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: In addition, the rate at which workers are quitting their jobs is elevated, a sign that workers are able to find another job when they seek one.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: And surveys show that businesses are finding it difficult to fill vacancies, and that households perceive jobs as plentiful.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Some other indicators are less clear.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: The labor force participation rate of prime-age workers has moved up in recent years but remains below pre-crisis levels.3In addition, wage growth has been moderate, consistent with low productivity growth but also an indication that the labor market is not excessively tight.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Looking ahead, the job market is likely to strengthen further.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Real gross domestic product in the United States is now reported to have risen 2-3/4 percent over the past four quarters, well above most estimates of its long-run trend.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Expansionary fiscal policy is expected to add to aggregate demand over the next few years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Many forecasters expect the unemployment rate to fall into the mid-3s and to remain there for an extended period.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: If that comes to pass, it will mean the lowest unemployment in the United States since the late 1960s.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: A historical comparisonBecause we have so little experience with very low unemployment, it is interesting to compare today's labor market with that earlier period.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Unemployment was below 4 percent from February 1966 through January 1970.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: During that time, inflation as measured by the price index for personal consumption expenditures increased from below 2 percent in 1965 to about 5 percent in 1970.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: In hindsight, unemployment is now widely thought to have been unsustainably low at that time and to have contributed to escalating inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: But how significant is this precedent for today?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: The U.S. economy has changed in many ways over the past 50 years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: By some estimates, the natural rate of unemployment is substantially lower now.4For example, the Congressional Budget Office now estimates that the natural rate was about 5‑3/4 percent (and rising) in the late 1960s, compared with 4-3/4 percent at present.5

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Rising education levels do point to a decline in the natural rate since the 1960s, because more highly educated people are less likely to be unemployed.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: The share of the population with a college degree has risen from less than 15 percent in the late 1960s to nearly 40 percent now, and the share with less than a high school degree has declined from 45 percent to about 5 percent.6Another important difference from the 1960s is that inflation has been low and stable for an extended period, which has better anchored inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Today policymakers have a greater appreciation of the role expectations play in inflation dynamics and a clearer commitment to maintaining low and stable inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Unfortunately, with the passage of a half-century and important changes in the structure of our economy and in central bank practices, in my view the historical comparison does not shed as much light as we might have hoped.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Questions prompted by a tight labor marketThe lack of useful historical precedent leaves us with some uncertainty about the answers to several important and challenging questions.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: First, estimates of the natural rate of unemployment by Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participants and others have drifted lower as unemployment has declined without much apparent reaction from inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: How reliable are these estimates?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Natural rate estimates have always been uncertain, and may be even more so now as inflation has become less responsive to the unemployment rate.7The anchoring of expectations is a welcome development and has likely played a role in flattening the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: But a flatter Phillips curve makes it harder to assess whether movements in inflation reflect the cyclical position of the economy or other influences.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Second, what would be the consequences for inflation if unemployment were to run well below the natural rate for an extended period?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: The flat Phillips curve suggests that the implications for inflation might not be large, although a very tight labor market could lead to larger, nonlinear effects.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Research on this question is ambiguous, again reflecting the limited historical experience.8We should also remember that where inflation expectations are well anchored, it is likely because central banks have kept inflation under control.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: If central banks were instead to try to exploit the nonresponsiveness of inflation to low unemployment and push resource utilization significantly and persistently past sustainable levels, the public might begin to question our commitment to low inflation, and expectations could come under upward pressure.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: So far, we see no signs of this.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: If anything, some measures of longer-term inflation expectations in the United States have edged lower in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Third, can persistently strong economic conditions pose financial stability risks?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Of course, strong economic conditions are a good thing!

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Such conditions can make the financial system better able to absorb shocks through strong balance sheets and investor confidence.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: But we have often seen confidence become overconfidence and lead to excessive borrowing and risk-taking, leaving the financial system more vulnerable.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Indeed, the fact that the two most recent U.S. recessions stemmed principally from financial imbalances, not high inflation, highlights the importance of closely monitoring financial conditions.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Today I see U.S. financial stability vulnerabilities as moderate and broadly in line with their long-run averages.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: While some asset prices are high by historical standards, I do not see broad signs of excessive borrowing or leverage.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: In addition, banks have far greater levels of capital and liquidity than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Fourth, while persistently strong economic conditions can pose risks to inflation and perhaps financial stability, we can also ask whether there may be lasting benefits.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: As I mentioned, a tight labor market could draw more people into the labor force.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: In fact, as the labor market has tightened, more workers have been moving back to work and off disability rolls.9There could also be benefits to productivity and potential growth.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: All told, though, the persistence of any such "positive hysteresis" benefits is uncertain, since, again, the historical evidence is sparse and inconclusive.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: As is often the case, in the current environment, significant uncertainty attends the process of making monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
text: Today, with the economy strong and risks to the outlook balanced, the case for continued gradual increases in the federal funds rate remains strong and broadly supported among FOMC participants.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Thank you for inviting me to join you today as part of this distinguished panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Our subject is the relationship between "center country" monetary policy and global financial conditions, and the policy implications of that relationship both for the center country and for other countries affected.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: This broad topic has been the subject of a great deal of research and discussion in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Today I will focus in particular on the role of U.S. monetary policy in driving global financial conditions and capital flows.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: To preview my conclusions, I will argue that, while global factors play an important role in influencing domestic financial conditions, the role of U.S. monetary policy is often exaggerated.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: And while financial globalization does pose some challenges for monetary policy, efforts to build stronger and more transparent policy frameworks and a more resilient financial system can reduce the adverse consequences of external shocks.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: The well-known Mundell-Fleming "trilemma" states that it is not possible to have all three of the following things: free capital mobility, a fixed exchange rate, and the ability to pursue an independent monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: The trilemma does not say that a flexible exchange rate will always fully insulate domestic economic conditions from external shocks.1And, indeed, that is not the case.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: We have seen that integration of global capital markets can make for difficult tradeoffs for some economies, whether they have fixed or floating exchange rate regimes.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Since the Fed is the central bank of the world's largest economy and issuer of the world's most widely used reserve currency, it is to be expected that the Fed's policy actions will spill over to other economies.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: To illustrate this point, the scatterplot on the left side offigure 1focuses on movements in interest rates and exchange rates following Federal Reserve policy announcements.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: As you can see, changes in U.S. interest rates after Fed policy actions (shown on the horizontal axis) lead to corresponding changes in the value of the dollar (shown on the vertical axis).

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: And because of the dollar's widespread use around the world, these changes in the dollar affect financial conditions abroad.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Fed policy-related movements in U.S. bond yields also tend to spill over to bond yields abroad, such as the German yields shown in the scatterplot on the right.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Such spillovers are to be expected in a world of highly integrated financial markets.2Asfigure 2shows, bond yields (left) and equity prices (right) around the world typically move together fairly closely.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: But the influence of U.S. monetary policy on global financial conditions should not be overstated.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: The Federal Reserve is not the only central bank whose actions affect global financial markets.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: In fact, the United States is the recipient as well as the originator of monetary policy spillovers.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: For example, as seen infigure 3, changes in German yields after European Central Bank policy decisions also pass through to U.S. yields.3More broadly, it is notable that although the Fed has raised its target interest rate six times since December 2015 and has begun to shrink its balance sheet, overall U.S. domestic financial conditions have gotten looser, in part due to improving global conditions and central bank policy abroad.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Much of the discussion of the spillovers of U.S. monetary policy focuses on their effects on financial conditions in emerging market economies (EMEs).

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Some observers have attributed the movements in international capital flowing to EMEs since the Global Financial Crisis primarily to monetary stimulus by the Fed and other advanced-economy central banks.4The data do not seem to me to fit this narrative particularly well.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: As illustrated by the blue dashed line in the left panel offigure 4, capital flows to EMEs were already very strong before the Global Financial Crisis, when the federal funds rate was comparatively high.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: The subsequent surge in capital flows in 2009, as the crisis was abating, largely reflects a rebound from the capital flow interruption during the crisis itself, though highly accommodative monetary policies in advanced economies doubtless also played a role.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Moreover, capital flows to EMEs started to ease after 2011, a period when the Federal Reserve continued to add accommodation and reduce yields through increases in its balance sheet, as shown in the right panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: And, more recently, capital flows to EMEs have picked up again despite the fact that the Fed has been removing accommodation since 2015.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: If U.S. monetary policy is not the major determinant, what other factors have been driving EME capital flows?

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: One prominent factor has been growth differentials between EMEs and advanced economies.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Infigure 5, the left panel shows that capital inflows to EMEs picked up post-crisis, in line with the widening of this growth differential, while the slowdown in inflows after 2011 coincides with its narrowing.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Another related determinant has been commodity prices, as shown in the right panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: The pickup in both global growth and commodity prices over the past couple of years explains a good part of the recent recovery of capital flows to EMEs.5

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Monetary stimulus by the Fed and other advanced-economy central banks played a relatively limited role in the surge of capital flows to EMEs in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: There is good reason to think that the normalization of monetary policies in advanced economies should continue to prove manageable for EMEs.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Fed policy normalization has proceeded without disruption to financial markets, and market participants' expectations for policy (the red symbols infigure 6) seem reasonably well aligned with policymakers' expectations in the Summary of Economic Projections (the black dots), suggesting that markets should not be surprised by our actions if the economy evolves in line with expectations.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: It also bears emphasizing that the EMEs themselves have made considerable progress in reducing vulnerabilities since the crisis-prone 1980s and 1990s.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Many EMEs have substantially improved their fiscal and monetary policy frameworks while adopting more flexible exchange rates, a policy that recent research shows provides better insulation from external financial shocks.6Corporate debt at risk--the debt of firms with limited debt service capacity--has been rising in EMEs, as shown infigure 7.7But this rise has been relatively limited outside of China and has begun to reverse as stronger global growth has pushed up earnings.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: All that said, I do not dismiss the prospective risks emanating from global policy normalization.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Some investors and institutions may not be well positioned for a rise in interest rates, even one that markets broadly anticipate.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: And, of course, future economic conditions may surprise us, as they often do.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Moreover, the linkages among monetary policy, asset prices, and the mood of global financial markets are not fully understood.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Some observers have argued that U.S. monetary policy also influences capital flows through its effects on global risk sentiment, with looser policy leading to more positive sentiment in markets and tighter policy depressing sentiment.8While those channels may well operate, research at both the Fed and the IMF suggests that actions by major central banks account for only a relatively small fraction of global financial volatility and capital flow movements.9

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: Nevertheless, risk sentiment will bear close watching as normalization proceeds around the world.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: What can the Federal Reserve do to foster continued financial stability and economic growth as normalization proceeds?

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: We will communicate our policy strategy as clearly and transparently as possible to help align expectations and avoid market disruptions.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
text: And we will continue to help build resilience in the financial system and support global efforts to do the same.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Thank you for this opportunity to speak at the 61st annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: At the Fed, we like to say that monetary policy is data dependent.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We say this to emphasize that policy is never on a preset course and will change as appropriate in response to incoming information.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: But that does not capture the breadth and depth of what data-dependent decisionmaking means to us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: From its beginnings more than a century ago, the Federal Reserve has gone to great lengths to collect and rigorously analyze the best information to make sound decisions for the public we serve.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The topic of this meeting, "Trucks and Terabytes: Integrating the 'New' and 'Old' Economies," captures the essence of a major challenge for data-dependent policymaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We must sort out in real time, as best we can, what the profound changes underway in the economy mean for issues such as the functioning of labor markets, the pace of productivity growth, and the forces driving inflation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Of course, issues like these have always been with us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Indeed, 100 years ago, some of the first Fed policymakers recognized the need for more timely information on the rapidly evolving state of industry and decided to create and publish production indexes for the United States.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Today I will pay tribute to the 100 years of dedicated—and often behind the scenes—work of those tracking change in the industrial landscape.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: I will then turn to three challenges our dynamic economy is posing for policy at present: First, what would the consequences of a sharp rise in the price of oil be for the U.S. economy?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: This question, which never seems far from relevance, is again drawing our attention after recent events in the Persian Gulf.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: While the question is familiar, technological advances in the energy sector are rapidly changing our assessment of the answer.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Second, with terabytes of data increasingly competing with truckloads of goods in economic importance, what are the best ways to measure output and productivity?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Put more provocatively, might the recent productivity slowdown be an artifact of antiquated measurement?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Third, how tight is the labor market?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Given our mandate of maximum employment and price stability, this question is at the very core of our work.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: But answering it in real time in a dynamic economy as jobs are gained in one area but lost in others is remarkably challenging.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced that job gains over the year through March were likely a half-million lower than previously reported.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: I will discuss how we are using big data to improve our grasp of the job market in the face of such revisions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: These three quite varied questions highlight the broad range of issues that currently come under the simple heading "data dependent."

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: After exploring them, I will comment briefly on recent developments in money markets and on monetary policy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: A Century of Industrial ProductionOur story of data dependence in the face of change begins when the Fed opened for business in 1914.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: World War I was breaking out in Europe, and over the next four years the war would fuel profound growth and transformation in the U.S. economy.1But you could not have seen this change in the gross national product data; the Department of Commerce did not publish those until 1942.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The Census Bureau had been running a census of manufactures since 1905, but that came only every five years—an eternity in the rapidly changing economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In need of more timely information, the Fed began creating and publishing a series of industrial output reports that soon evolved into industrial production indexes.2The indexes initially comprised 22 basic commodities, chosen in part because they covered the major industrial groups, but also for the practical reason that data were available with less than a one-month lag.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The Fed's efforts were among the earliest in creating timely measures of aggregate production.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Over the century of its existence, our industrial production team has remained at the frontier of economic measurement, using the most advanced techniques to monitor U.S. industry and nimbly track changes in production.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: What Are the Consequences of an Oil Price Spike?Let's turn now to the first question of the consequences of an oil price spike.Figure 1shows U.S. oil production since 1920.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: After rising fairly steadily through the early 1970s, production began a long period of gradual decline.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: By 2005, production was at about the same level as it had been 50 years earlier.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Since then, remarkable advances in the technology for finding and extracting oil have led to a rapid increase in production to levels higher than ever before.3In 2018, the United States became the world's largest oil producer.4Oil exports have surged, imports have fallen (figure 2), and the U.S. Energy Information Administration projects that this month, for the first time in many decades, the United States will be a net exporter of oil.5

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: As monetary policymakers, we closely monitor developments in oil markets because disruptions in these markets have played a role in several U.S. recessions and in the Great Inflation of the 1960s and 1970s.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Traditionally, we assessed that a sharp rise in the price of oil would have a strong negative effect on consumers and businesses and, hence, on the U.S. economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Today a higher oil price would still cause dislocations and hardship for many, but with exports and imports nearly balanced, the higher price paid by consumers is roughly offset by higher earnings of workers and firms in the U.S. oil industry.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Moreover, because it is now easier to ramp up oil production, a sustained price rise can quickly boost output, providing a shock absorber in the face of supply disruptions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Thus, setting aside the effects of geopolitical uncertainty that may accompany higher oil prices, we now judge that a price spike would likely have nearly offsetting effects on U.S. gross domestic product (GDP).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: How Should We Measure Output and Productivity?Let's now turn to the second question of how to best measure output and productivity.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: While there are some subtleties in measuring oil output, we know how to count barrels of oil.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Measuring the overall level of goods and services produced in the economy is fundamentally messier, because it requires adding apples and oranges—and automobiles and myriad other goods and services.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The hard-working statisticians creating the official statistics regularly adapt the data sources and methods so that, insofar as possible, the measured data provide accurate indicators of the state of the economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Periods of rapid change present particular challenges, and it can take time for the measurement system to adapt to fully and accurately reflect the changes in the economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The advance of technology has long presented measurement challenges.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In 1987, Nobel Prize–winning economist Robert Solow quipped that "you can see the computer age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: "6In the second half of the 1990s, this measurement puzzle was at the heart of monetary policymaking.7Chairman Alan Greenspan famously argued that the United States was experiencing the dawn of a new economy, and that potential and actual output were likely understated in official statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Where others saw capacity constraints and incipient inflation, Greenspan saw a productivity boom that would leave room for very low unemployment without inflation pressures.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In light of the uncertainty it faced, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) judged that the appropriate risk‑management approach called for refraining from interest rate increases unless and until there were clearer signs of rising inflation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Under this policy, unemployment fell near record lows without rising inflation, and later revisions to GDP measurement showed appreciably faster productivity growth.8

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: This episode illustrates a key challenge to making data-dependent policy in real time: Good decisions require good data, but the data in hand are seldom as good as we would like.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Sound decisionmaking therefore requires the application of good judgment and a healthy dose of risk management.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Productivity is again presenting a puzzle.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Official statistics currently show productivity growth slowing significantly in recent years, with the growth in output per hour worked falling from more than 3 percent a year from 1995 to 2003 to less than half that pace since then.9Analysts are actively debating three alternative explanations for this apparent slowdown: First, the slowdown may be real and may persist indefinitely as productivity growth returns to more‑normal levels after a brief golden age.10Second, the slowdown may instead be a pause of the sort that often accompanies fundamental technological change, so that productivity gains from recent technology advances will appear over time as society adjusts.11Third, the slowdown may be overstated, perhaps greatly, because of measurement issues akin to those at work in the 1990s.12At this point, we cannot know which of these views may gain widespread acceptance, and monetary policy will play no significant role in how this puzzle is resolved.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: As in the late 1990s, however, we are carefully assessing the implications of possibly mismeasured productivity gains.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Moreover, productivity growth seems to have moved up over the past year after a long period at very low levels; we do not know whether that welcome trend will be sustained.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Recent research suggests that current official statistics may understate productivity growth by missing a significant part of the growing value we derive from fast internet connections and smartphones.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: These technologies, which were just emerging 15 years ago, are now ubiquitous (figure 3).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We can now be constantly connected to the accumulated knowledge of humankind and receive near instantaneous updates on the lives of friends far and wide.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: And, adding to the measurement challenge, many of these services are free, which is to say, not explicitly priced.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: How should we value the luxury of never needing to ask for directions?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Or the peace and tranquility afforded by speedy resolution of those contentious arguments over the trivia of the moment?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Researchers have tried to answer these questions in various ways.13For example, Fed researchers have recently proposed a novel approach to measuring the value of services consumers derive from cellphones and other devices based on the volume of data flowing over those connections.14Taking their accounting at face value, GDP growth would have been about 1/2 percentage point higher since 2007, which is an appreciable change and would be very good news.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Growth over the previous couple of decades would also have been about 1/4 percentage point higher as well, implying that measurement issues of this sort likely account for only part of the productivity slowdown in current statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Research in this area is at an early stage, but this example illustrates the depth of analysis supporting our data-dependent decisionmaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: How Tight Is the Labor Market?Let me now turn from the measurement issues raised by the information age to an issue that has long been at the center of monetary policymaking: How tight is the labor market?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Answering this question is central to our outlook for both of our dual-mandate goals of maximum employment and price stability.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: While this topic is always front and center in our thinking, I am raising it today to illustrate how we are using big data to inform policymaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Until recently, the official data showed job gains over the year through March 2019 of about 210,000 a month, which is far higher than necessary to absorb new entrants into the labor force and thus hold the unemployment rate constant.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In August, the BLS publicly previewed the benchmark data revision coming in February 2020, and the news was that job gains over this period were more like 170,000 per month—a meaningfully lower number that itself remains subject to revision.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The pace of job gains is hard to pin down in real time largely because of the dynamism of our economy: Many new businesses open and others close every month, creating some jobs and ending others, and definitive data on this turnover arrive with a substantial lag.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Thus, initial data are, in part, sophisticated guesses based on what is known as the birth–death model of firms.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Several years ago, we began a collaboration with the payroll processing firm ADP to construct a measure of payroll employment from their data set, which covers about 20 percent of the nation's private workforce and is available to us with a roughly one-week delay.15As described in a recent research paper, we constructed a measure that provides an independent read on payroll employment that complements the official statistics.16While experience is still limited with the new measure, we find promising evidence that it can refine our real-time picture of job gains.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: For example, in the first eight months of 2008, as the Great Recession was getting underway, the official monthly employment data showed total job losses of about 750,000 (figure 4).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: A later benchmark revision told a much bleaker story, with declines of about 1.5 million.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Our new measure, had it been available in 2008, would have been much closer to the revised data, alerting us that the job situation might be considerably worse than the official data suggested.17

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We believe that the new measure may help us better understand job market conditions in real time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The preview of the BLS benchmark revision leaves average job gains over the year through March solidly above the pace required to accommodate growth in the workforce over that time, but where we had seen a booming job market, we now see more-moderate growth.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The benchmark revision will not directly affect data for job gains since March, but experience with past revisions suggests that some part of the benchmark will likely carry forward.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Thus, the currently reported job gains of 157,000 per month on average over the past three months may well be revised somewhat lower.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Based on a range of data and analysis, including our new measure, we now judge that, even allowing for such a revision, job gains remain above the level required to provide jobs for new entrants to the jobs market over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Of course, the pace of job gains is only one of many job market issues that figure into our assessment of how the economy is performing relative to our maximum-employment mandate and our assessment of any inflationary pressures arising in the job market.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: What Does Data Dependence Mean at Present?In summary, data dependence is, and always has been, at the heart of policymaking at the Federal Reserve.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We are always seeking out new and better sources of information and refining our analysis of that information to keep us abreast of conditions as our economy constantly reinvents itself.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Before wrapping up, I will discuss recent developments in money markets and the current stance of monetary policy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Our influence on the financial conditions that affect employment and inflation is indirect.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The Federal Reserve sets two overnight interest rates: the interest rate paid on banks' reserve balances and the rate on our reverse repurchase agreements.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We use these two administered rates to keep a market-determined rate, the federal funds rate, within a target range set by the FOMC.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We rely on financial markets to transmit these rates through a variety of channels to the rates paid by households and businesses—and to financial conditions more broadly.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: In mid-September, an important channel in the transmission process—wholesale funding markets—exhibited unexpectedly intense volatility.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Payments to meet corporate tax obligations and to purchase Treasury securities triggered notable liquidity pressures in money markets.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Overnight interest rates spiked, and the effective federal funds rate briefly moved above the FOMC's target range.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: To counter these pressures, we began conducting temporary open market operations.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: These operations have kept the federal funds rate in the target range and alleviated money market strains more generally.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: While a range of factors may have contributed to these developments, it is clear that without a sufficient quantity of reserves in the banking system, even routine increases in funding pressures can lead to outsized movements in money market interest rates.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: This volatility can impede the effective implementation of monetary policy, and we are addressing it.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Indeed, my colleagues and I will soon announce measures to add to the supply of reserves over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Consistent with a decision we made in January, our goal is to provide an ample supply of reserves to ensure that control of the federal funds rate and other short-term interest rates is exercised primarily by setting our administered rates and not through frequent market interventions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Of course, we will not hesitate to conduct temporary operations if needed to foster trading in the federal funds market at rates within the target range.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Reserve balances are one among several items on the liability side of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet, and demand for these liabilities—notably, currency in circulation—grows over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Hence, increasing the supply of reserves or even maintaining a given level over time requires us to increase the size of our balance sheet.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: As we indicated in our March statement on balance sheet normalization, at some point, we will begin increasing our securities holdings to maintain an appropriate level of reserves.18That time is now upon us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: I want to emphasize that growth of our balance sheet for reserve management purposes should in no way be confused with the large-scale asset purchase programs that we deployed after the financial crisis.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Neither the recent technical issues nor the purchases of Treasury bills we are contemplating to resolve them should materially affect the stance of monetary policy, to which I now turn.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Our goal in monetary policy is to promote maximum employment and stable prices, which we interpret as inflation running closely around our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: At present, the jobs and inflation pictures are favorable.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Many indicators show a historically strong labor market, with solid job gains, the unemployment rate at half-century lows, and rising prime-age labor force participation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Wages are rising, especially for those with lower-paying jobs.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Inflation is somewhat below our symmetric 2 percent objective but has been gradually firming over the past few months.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: FOMC participants continue to see a sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective as most likely.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: But there are risks to this favorable outlook, principally from global developments.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Growth around much of the world has weakened over the past year and a half, and uncertainties around trade, Brexit, and other issues pose risks to the outlook.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: As those factors have evolved, my colleagues and I have shifted our views about appropriate monetary policy toward a lower path for the federal funds rate and have lowered its target range by 50 basis points.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We believe that our policy actions are providing support for the outlook.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Looking ahead, policy is not on a preset course.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: The next FOMC meeting is several weeks away, and we will be carefully monitoring incoming information.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: We will be data dependent, assessing the outlook and risks to the outlook on a meeting-by-meeting basis.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
text: Taking all that into account, we will act as appropriate to support continued growth, a strong job market, and inflation moving back to our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: This year's symposium topic is "Challenges for Monetary Policy," and for the Federal Reserve those challenges flow from our mandate to foster maximum employment and price stability.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: From this perspective, our economy is now in a favorable place, and I will describe how we are working to sustain these conditions in the face of significant risks we have been monitoring.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The current U.S. expansion has entered its 11th year and is now the longest on record.1The unemployment rate has fallen steadily throughout the expansion and has been near half-century lows since early 2018.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: But that rate alone does not fully capture the benefits of this historically strong job market.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Labor force participation by people in their prime working years has been rising.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: While unemployment for minorities generally remains higher than for the workforce as a whole, the rate for African Americans, at 6 percent, is the lowest since the government began tracking it in 1972.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: For the past few years, wages have been increasing the most for people at the lower end of the wage scale.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that this job market is the best anyone can recall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We increasingly hear reports that employers are training workers who lack required skills, adapting jobs to the needs of employees with family responsibilities, and offering second chances to people who need one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Inflation has been surprisingly stable during the expansion: not falling much when the economy was weak and not rising much as the expansion gained strength.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Inflation ran close to our symmetric 2 percent objective for most of last year but has been running somewhat below 2 percent this year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Thus, after a decade of progress toward maximum employment and price stability, the economy is close to both goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Our challenge now is to do what monetary policy can do to sustain the expansion so that the benefits of the strong jobs market extend to more of those still left behind, and so that inflation is centered firmly around 2 percent.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Today I will explore what history tells us about sustaining long, steady expansions.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: A good place to start is with the passage of the Employment Act of 1946, which stated that it is the "continuing policy and responsibility of the Federal Government ... to promote maximum employment, production, and purchasing power.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: "2Some version of these goals has been in place ever since.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: I will divide the history since World War II into three eras organized around some well-known "Greats."

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The first era comprises the postwar years through the Great Inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The second era brought the Great Moderation but ended in the Great Recession.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The third era is still under way, and time will tell what "Greats" may emerge.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Each era presents a key question for the Fed and for society more generally.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The first era raises the question whether a central bank can resist the temptations that led to the Great Inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The second era raises the question whether long expansions supported by better monetary policy inevitably lead to destabilizing financial excesses like those seen in the Great Moderation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The third era confronts us with the question of how best to promote sustained prosperity in a world of slow global growth, low inflation, and low interest rates.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Near the end of my remarks, I will discuss the current context, and the ways these questions are shaping policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Era I, 1950–1982: Policy Breeds Macroeconomic Instability and the Great InflationThe late 1940s were a period of adjustment to a peacetime economy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: As the 1940s turned to the 1950s, the state of knowledge about how best to promote macroeconomic stability was limited.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The 1950s and early 1960s saw the economy oscillating sharply between recession and growth above 6 percent (figure 1, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Three expansions and contractions came in quick succession.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: With the benefit of hindsight, the lack of stability is generally attributed to "stop and go" stabilization policy, as monetary and fiscal authorities grappled with how best to modulate the use of their blunt but powerful tools.3

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Beginning in the mid-1960s, "stop and go" policy gave way to "too much go and not enough stop"—not enough, that is, to quell rising inflation pressures.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Both inflation and inflation expectations ratcheted upward through four expansions until the Fed, under Chairman Paul Volcker, engineered a definitive stop in the early 1980s (figure 1, panel C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Each of the expansions in the Great Inflation period ended with monetary policy tightening in response to rising inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Policymakers came out of the Great Inflation era with a clear understanding that it was essential to anchor inflation expectations at some low level.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: But many believed that central bankers would find it difficult to ignore the temptation of short-term employment gains at the cost of higher inflation down the road.4

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Era II, 1983 through 2009: the Great Moderation and Great RecessionAs the second era began, inflation was falling, and it continued to fall for about a decade (figure 2, panel C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In 1993, core inflation, which omits the volatile food and energy components, first fell below 2.5 percent, and has since remained in the narrow range of 0.9 percent to 2.5 percent.5Greater success on price stability came with greater success on employment.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Expansions in this era were longer and more stable than before (figure 2, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The era saw two of the three longest U.S. expansions up to that point in history.6

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Anchored inflation expectations helped make this win-win outcome possible, by giving the Fed latitude to support employment when necessary without destabilizing inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The Fed was cutting, not raising, rates in the months prior to the end of the first two expansions in this era, and the ensuing recessions were mild by historical standards.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: And twice during the long expansion of the 1990s, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) eased policy in response to threats to growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In 1995, responding to evidence of slowing in the United States and abroad, the FOMC reduced the federal funds rate over a few months.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In 1998, the Russian debt default and the related collapse of the hedge fund Long‑Term Capital Management rocked financial markets that were already fragile from the Asian financial crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Given the risks posed to the U.S. economy, the FOMC again lowered the federal funds rate over a period of months until events quieted.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The 10-year expansion weathered both events with no discernible inflation cost.7

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: By the turn of the century, it was beginning to look like financial excesses and global events would pose the main threats to stability in this new era rather than overheating and rising inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The collapse of the tech stock bubble in 2000 and the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks played key roles in precipitating a slowdown that turned into a recession.8And the next expansion, as we are all painfully aware, ended with the collapse of a housing bubble and the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Thus, this second era provided good reason for optimism about the Fed's ability to deliver stable inflation, but also raised a question about whether long expansions inevitably lead to destabilizing financial excesses.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Era III, 2010 and After: Monetary Policy and the Emerging New NormalThe third era began in 2010 as the recovery from the Great Recession was taking hold.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: My focus in discussing this era will be on a "new normal" that is becoming apparent in the wake of the crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: I will fast-forward past the early years of the expansion and pick up the story in December 2015.9The unemployment rate had fallen from a peak of 10 percent to 5 percent, roughly equal to the median FOMC participant's estimate of the natural rate of unemployment at the time.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: At this point, the Committee decided that it was prudent to begin gradually raising the federal funds rate based on the closely monitored premise that the increasingly healthy economy called for more-normal interest rates.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The premise was generally borne out: Growth from the end of 2015 to the end of 2018 averaged 2.5 percent, a bit above the 2.2 percent rate over the previous five years (figure 2, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The unemployment rate fell below 4 percent, and inflation moved up and remained close to our 2 percent objective through much of 2018 (figure 2, panels B and C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: That brings us to 2019.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Before turning to issues occupying center stage at present, I want to address a long-running issue that I discussed here last year: tracking the "stars" that serve as guideposts for monetary policy.10These include u*, the natural rate of unemployment, and r*, the neutral real rate of interest.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Unlike celestial stars, these stars move unpredictably and cannot be directly observed.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We must judge their locations as best we can based on incoming data and then add an element of risk management to be able to use them as guides.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Since 2012, declining unemployment has had surprisingly little effect on inflation, prompting a steady decline in estimates of u* (figure 3).11Standard estimates of r* have declined between 2 and 3 percentage points over the past two decades.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Some argue that the effective decline is even larger.12Incorporating a lower value of u* into policymaking does not require a significant change in our approach.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The significant fall in r*, however, may demand more fundamental change.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: A lower r* combined with low inflation means that interest rates will run, on average, significantly closer to their effective lower bound.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The key question raised by this era, then, is how we can best support maximum employment and price stability in a world with a low neutral interest rate.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Current Policy and the Three Key QuestionsLet me turn now to the current implications for monetary policy of the questions raised by these three eras.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The first era raised the question of whether the Fed can avoid excessive inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Inflation has averaged less than 2 percent over the past 25 years, and low inflation has been the main concern for the past decade.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Low inflation seems to be the problem of this era, not high inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Nonetheless, in the unlikely event that signs of too-high inflation return, we have proven tools to address such a situation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The second era's question—whether long expansions inevitably breed financial excesses—is a challenging and timely one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Hyman Minsky long argued that, as an expansion continues and memories of the previous downturn fade, financial risk management deteriorates and risks are increasingly underappreciated.13This observation has spurred much discussion.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: At the end of the day, we cannot prevent people from finding ways to take excessive financial risks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: But we can work to make sure that they bear the costs of their decisions, and that the financial system as a whole continues to function effectively.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Since the crisis, Congress, the Fed, and other regulatory authorities here and around the world have taken substantial steps to achieve these goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Banks and other key institutions have significantly more capital and more stable funding than before the crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We comprehensively review financial stability every quarter and release our assessments twice a year to highlight areas of concern and allow oversight of our efforts.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We have not seen unsustainable borrowing, financial booms, or other excesses of the sort that occurred at times during the Great Moderation, and I continue to judge overall financial stability risks to be moderate.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: That leaves the third question of how, in this low r* world, the Fed can best support the economy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: A low neutral interest rate presents both near-term and longer-term challenges.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: I will begin with the current context.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Because today's setting is both challenging and unique in many ways, it may be useful to lay out some general principles for assessing and implementing appropriate policy and to describe how we have been applying those principles.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Through the FOMC's setting of the federal funds rate target range and our communications about the likely path forward for policy and the economy, we seek to influence broader financial conditions to promote maximum employment and price stability.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In forming judgments about the appropriate stance of policy, the Committee digests a broad range of data and other information to assess the current state of the economy, the most likely outlook for the future, and meaningful risks to that outlook.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Because the most important effects of monetary policy are felt with uncertain lags of a year or more, the Committee must attempt to look through what may be passing developments and focus on things that seem likely to affect the outlook over time or that pose a material risk of doing so.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Risk management enters our decisionmaking because of both the uncertainty about the effects of recent developments and the uncertainty we face regarding structural aspects of the economy, including the natural rate of unemployment and the neutral rate of interest.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: It will at times be appropriate for us to tilt policy one way or the other because of prominent risks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Finally, we have a responsibility to explain what we are doing and why we are doing it so the American people and their elected representatives in Congress can provide oversight and hold us accountable.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We have much experience in addressing typical macroeconomic developments under this framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: But fitting trade policy uncertainty into this framework is a new challenge.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Setting trade policy is the business of Congress and the Administration, not that of the Fed.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Our assignment is to use monetary policy to foster our statutory goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In principle, anything that affects the outlook for employment and inflation could also affect the appropriate stance of monetary policy, and that could include uncertainty about trade policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: There are, however, no recent precedents to guide any policy response to the current situation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Moreover, while monetary policy is a powerful tool that works to support consumer spending, business investment, and public confidence, it cannot provide a settled rulebook for international trade.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We can, however, try to look through what may be passing events, focus on how trade developments are affecting the outlook, and adjust policy to promote our objectives.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: This approach is illustrated by the way incoming data have shaped the likely path of policy this year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The outlook for the U.S. economy since the start of the year has continued to be a favorable one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Business investment and manufacturing have weakened, but solid job growth and rising wages have been driving robust consumption and supporting moderate growth overall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: As the year has progressed, we have been monitoring three factors that are weighing on this favorable outlook: slowing global growth, trade policy uncertainty, and muted inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The global growth outlook has been deteriorating since the middle of last year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Trade policy uncertainty seems to be playing a role in the global slowdown and in weak manufacturing and capital spending in the United States.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Inflation fell below our objective at the start of the year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: It appears to be moving back up closer to our symmetric 2 percent objective, but there are concerns about a more prolonged shortfall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Committee participants have generally reacted to these developments and the risks they pose by shifting down their projections of the appropriate federal funds rate path.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Along with July's rate cut, the shifts in the anticipated path of policy have eased financial conditions and help explain why the outlook for inflation and employment remains largely favorable.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Turning to the current context, we are carefully watching developments as we assess their implications for the U.S. outlook and the path of monetary policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The three weeks since our July FOMC meeting have been eventful, beginning with the announcement of new tariffs on imports from China.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We have seen further evidence of a global slowdown, notably in Germany and China.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Geopolitical events have been much in the news, including the growing possibility of a hard Brexit, rising tensions in Hong Kong, and the dissolution of the Italian government.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Financial markets have reacted strongly to this complex, turbulent picture.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Equity markets have been volatile.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Long-term bond rates around the world have moved down sharply to near post-crisis lows.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Meanwhile, the U.S. economy has continued to perform well overall, driven by consumer spending.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Job creation has slowed from last year's pace but is still above overall labor force growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Inflation seems to be moving up closer to 2 percent.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Based on our assessment of the implications of these developments, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The Three Questions in the Longer RunLooking back over the three eras, monetary policy has evolved to address new challenges as they have arisen.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The inflation targeting regime that emerged after the Great Inflation has led to vastly improved outcomes for employment and price stability around the world.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: One result has been much longer expansions, which often brought with them the buildup of financial risk.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: This new pattern has led us to understand that assuring financial stability over time requires much greater resilience in our financial system, particularly for our largest, most complex banks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: As we look back over the decade since the end of the financial crisis, we can again see fundamental economic changes that call for a reassessment of our policy framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: The current era has been characterized by much lower neutral interest rates, disinflationary pressures, and slower growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We face heightened risks of lengthy, difficult-to-escape periods in which our policy interest rate is pinned near zero.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: To address this new normal, we are conducting a public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications—the first of its kind for the Federal Reserve.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We are evaluating the pros and cons of strategies that aim to reverse past misses of our inflation objective.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We are examining the monetary policy tools we have used both in calm times and in crisis, and we are asking whether we should expand our toolkit.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: In addition, we are looking at how we might improve the communication of our policy framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: Public engagement, unprecedented in scope for the Fed, is at the heart of this effort.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: ThroughFed Listensevents live-streamed on the internet, we are hearing a diverse range of perspectives not only from academic experts, but also from representatives of consumer, labor, business, community, and other groups.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We have begun a series of FOMC meetings at which we will discuss these questions.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: We will continue reporting on our discussions in the FOMC minutes and share our conclusions when we finish the review next year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
text: I will conclude by saying that we are deeply committed to fulfilling our mandate in this challenging era, and I look forward to the valuable insights that will, I am confident, be shared at this symposium.
