title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Seventy-five years ago this month, the foremost economic and policy minds of their generation gathered in a sleepy mountain town in New England.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: While World War II still raged, they envisioned a new international monetary system with rules, procedures, and institutions—including the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank—to promote recovery and stability in a war-ravaged world.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Today we gather in Paris, the City of Light, to recognize their vision.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: The Bretton Woods institutions played a pivotal role after the war in rebuilding economies and in facilitating the international economic relations that are essential to prosperity.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Generations later, the World Bank and the IMF continue to play important roles in fostering global monetary cooperation, financial stability, and international trade, as well as in promoting sustainable economic growth and reducing poverty.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In 1944, those who sat around the table at the Mount Washington Hotel knew that the trauma and tragedy of the war and the Great Depression had fundamentally altered the economic systems that preceded them.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: For us, around our dinner tables tonight, a decade has passed since the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Although in no way comparable to the devastating events of the 1930s and 1940s, the crisis represents the deepest and broadest financial upheaval since that era, and in many ways, we, too, are grappling with a changed world.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Today's conference has looked at this post-crisis environment and the issues we now face from many angles.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: I am grateful to the Banque de France for organizing this important event and to the outstanding speakers for their deep insights.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Tonight I will offer some thoughts on this new environment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: I will begin with a discussion of current economic conditions in the United States, and then highlight some significant structural changes in the environment facing monetary policymakers in the post-crisis era.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Finally, I will consider how these structural changes are affecting the framework in which we conduct monetary policy, highlighting the Federal Reserve System's ongoing review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: The U.S. economy is now in its 11th consecutive year of growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Unemployment has steadily declined from its 10 percent post-crisis peak and has now remained at or below 4 percent for more than a year, the longest stretch in a half century.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: A strong labor market with plentiful job openings has supported labor force participation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: After rising only grudgingly early in the recovery, wages have moved up the past few years.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Some groups, such as African Americans, Hispanics, and rural Americans, continue to face long-standing challenges, but the benefits of this strong job market are increasingly widely shared.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: At outreach events we are holding across the United States, we are hearing loud and clear that this long recovery is now benefiting low- and moderate-income communities to a greater extent than has been felt for decades.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Many people who have struggled to stay in the workforce are now getting an opportunity to add new and better chapters to their life stories.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Solid growth has sustained this strong labor market.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Most recently, U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of just over 3 percent in the first quarter, similar to last year's strong pace.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: But first-quarter growth was driven largely by net exports and inventories—two volatile spending categories that are typically not dependable indicators of ongoing momentum.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Indeed, overall growth in the second quarter appears to have moderated.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Growth in consumer spending, which was soft in the first quarter, looks to have bounced back, but business fixed investment growth seems to have slowed notably.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Moreover, the manufacturing sector has been weak since the beginning of the year, in part weighed down by the softer business spending, weaker growth in the global economy, and, as our business contacts tell us, concerns about trade tensions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Despite low unemployment and solid overall growth, inflation pressures remain muted.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: After running close to the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) symmetric 2 percent objective over much of last year, both overall consumer price inflation and core inflation moved down earlier this year.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: We currently estimate that the change in the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index was 1.7 percent over the 12 months ending in June.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In our baseline outlook, we expect growth in the United States to remain solid, labor markets to stay strong, and inflation to move back up and run near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Uncertainties about this outlook have increased, however, particularly regarding trade developments and global growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In addition, issues such as the U.S. federal debt ceiling and Brexit remain unresolved.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: FOMC participants have also raised concerns about a more prolonged shortfall in inflation below our 2 percent target.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Market-based measures of inflation compensation have shifted down, and some survey-based expectations measures are near the bottom of their historical ranges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Many FOMC participants judged at the time of our most recent meeting in June that the combination of these factors strengthens the case for a somewhat more accommodative stance of policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: We are carefully monitoring these developments and assessing their implications for the U.S economic outlook and inflation, and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: We will also assess these developments in the context of the broader structural changes monetary policymakers have been facing since the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: I will focus on three tonight: the changed macroeconomic backdrop, the expanded toolkit, and the heightened focus on communication and transparency.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In the United States, from the mid-1980s to right before the Great Recession, PCE inflation averaged 2.6 percent a year, GDP growth 3.4 percent, and the interest rate on a 10-year Treasury note 6.5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Since the trough of the Great Recession, average inflation and output growth are around 1 percentage point lower, and the 10-year Treasury rate has averaged 2.4 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: These declines are not unique to the United States.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Average inflation rates for the other major advanced economies have declined by almost half, while the inflation rates of major emerging market economies are less than one-fifth of what they were.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Indeed, with few exceptions, we are all facing lower rates of interest, growth, and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In a number of countries, including the United States, these declines have been accompanied by strong labor markets and a much lower unemployment rate.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Such changes in the macroeconomic environment are significant because the long-run normal levels of inflation, output, interest rates, and the unemployment rate are important structural features by which we guide policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Standard estimates of the natural rate of unemployment—u*—and the neutral rate of interest—r*—have been declining for 2 decades, and particularly since the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Many factors are contributing to these changes—well-anchored inflation expectations in the context of improved monetary policy, demographics, globalization, slower productivity growth, greater demand for safe assets, and weaker links between unemployment and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: And these factors seem likely to persist.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: If that happens, the neutral rate of interest will remain low, and policymakers will continue to operate in an environment in which the risk of hitting the effective lower bound is much higher than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: This proximity to the lower bound poses new complications for central banks and calls for new ideas.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: It is true that many of these features have been with us for some time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Trend inflation, productivity, and interest rates were declining well before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: But, for monetary policymakers in that era, the threat of high inflation felt proximate, the hard-fought battle to control high inflation having been just recently won.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Technological progress seemed likely to continue to sustain rapid increases in productivity—an outcome we continue to await.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: And the effective lower bound for interest rates was mainly a theoretical concern, except of course in Japan.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: The changes to the macroeconomic environment may have been in train earlier, but the crisis seems to have accelerated the process.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: The world in which policymakers are now operating is discretely different in important ways from the one before the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: I should also note, as is fitting given this event and this audience, that since the crisis policymakers are even more keenly aware of the relevance of global factors to our policies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: The global nature of the financial crisis and the channels through which it spread sharply highlight the interconnectedness of our economic, financial, and policy environments.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: U.S. economic developments affect the rest of the world, and the reverse is also true.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: For example, the stresses surrounding the euro crisis and, later, the China-related volatility events in 2015 and 2016 led to a general pullback in demand for risky assets that put downward pressure on U.S. interest rates and weighed on U.S. confidence and growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In addition, we have seen how monetary policy in one country can influence economic and financial conditions in others through financial markets, trade, and confidence channels.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Pursuing our domestic mandates in this new world requires that we understand the anticipated effects of these interconnections and incorporate them into our policy decisionmaking.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: A second important feature of this new world is the tools central bankers now have to fight recessions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In the face of the dramatic economic and financial collapse during the crisis, policymakers quickly exhausted conventional monetary policy tools and employed a range of unconventional measures to support their economies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: In the United States, these measures included new forms of forward guidance and a range of balance sheet policies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Broadly across different economies, so-called unconventional monetary policies have generally been successful at lowering interest rates and supporting economic recovery, though cyclical and structural headwinds have made achieving our inflation targets a challenge.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: A legacy of the crisis is that policymakers now have a broader range of tested tools to turn to the next time the effective lower bound is reached.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: We must continue to assess additional strategies and tools to bolster our economies and meet our inflation and employment mandates.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Finally, the crisis and Great Recession brought into stark relief the need for transparency and accountability for central banks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Central bank communication is increasingly important and increasingly challenging.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: It is important because clear, transparent communication about the economy, the risks, and our policy responses is critical for the effectiveness of our tools and for our accountability to the public in a democratic society.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: It is challenging, because we are operating in a changing macroeconomic environment with tools that, while no longer new, remain less familiar to the public.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Moreover, our audience has become more varied, more attuned to our actions, and less trusting of public institutions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Gone are the days when the Federal Reserve Chair could joke, as my predecessor Alan Greenspan did, "If I turn out to be particularly clear, you've probably misunderstood what I said.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: "1Central banks must speak to Main Street, as well as Wall Street, in ways we have not in the past, and Main Street is listening and engaged.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Where does this leave us, and how should policymakers adapt to this new environment?

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Recognizing challenges posed by the changing structure of the economy, the need for effective policy responses, and the importance of clear communication, central banks are taking a closer look at their strategies and the range of tools currently at their disposal.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: For example, the Bank of Canada examines its framework every five years as part of the renewal of its inflation-control agreement with the federal government.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Canadian officials have announced the bank will "assess a broad range of monetary policy frameworks ahead of the renewal in 2021" of this agreement.2The Bank of England commissioned a review over the past year of the future of the United Kingdom's financial system and what it might mean for the bank's agenda, toolkit, and capabilities.3For our part, the Federal Reserve is conducting, for the first time, a public review of the strategy, tools, and communications that we use to promote our goals of maximum employment and price stability.4The heart of this review has been a series ofFed Listensevents around the country, in every Reserve Bank District, to hear directly from the constituencies we serve.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: These events have been live-streamed on the internet.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Last month, we hosted a research conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago to explore ways to more effectively and sustainably achieve our mandated goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Beginning soon, the FOMC will devote time at its regular meetings to assessing the lessons from these events.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: We will publicly report the conclusions of our discussions, likely during the first half of next year.5

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Other central banks, many represented in this room, are also looking deeply at the challenges posed by the current environment and assessing tools and strategies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: I look forward to learning from your experiences and sharing ours in the coming months and years as we face the trials and opportunities of this new era.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: For all of us, the turmoil that preceded this new world was severe, although not as extreme as that faced by those around the table in Bretton Woods 75 years ago.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
text: Tonight let us celebrate their success and strive so that our vision for the future of the global economic and financial system proves as durable and as effective.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: It is a pleasure to speak at the Council on Foreign Relations.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: I will begin with a progress report on the broad public review my Federal Reserve colleagues and I are conducting of the strategy, tools, and communication practices we use to achieve the objectives Congress has assigned to us by law—maximum employment and price stability, or the dual mandate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Then I will discuss the outlook for the U.S. economy and monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: I look forward to the discussion that will follow.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: During our public review, we are seeking perspectives from people across the nation, and we are doing so through open public meetings live-streamed on the internet.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Let me share some of the thinking behind this review, which is the first of its nature we have undertaken.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The Fed is insulated from short-term political pressures—what is often referred to as our "independence."

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Congress chose to insulate the Fed this way because it had seen the damage that often arises when policy bends to short-term political interests.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Central banks in major democracies around the world have similar independence.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Along with this independence comes the obligation to explain clearly what we are doing and why we are doing it, so that the public and their elected representatives in Congress can hold us accountable.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: But real accountability demands more of us than clear explanation: We must listen.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We must actively engage those we serve to understand how we can more effectively and faithfully use the powers they have entrusted to us.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: That is why we are formally and publicly opening our decisionmaking to suggestions, scrutiny, and critique.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: With unemployment low, the economy growing, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective, this is a good time to undertake such a review.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Another factor motivating the review is that the challenges of monetary policymaking have changed in a fundamental way in recent years.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Interest rates are lower than in the past, and likely to remain so.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The persistence of lower rates means that, when the economy turns down, interest rates will more likely fall close to zero—their effective lower bound (ELB).

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Proximity to the ELB poses new problems to central banks and calls for new ideas.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We hope to benefit from the best thinking on these issues.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: At the heart of the review are ourFed Listensevents, which include town hall–style meetings in all 12 Federal Reserve Districts.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: These meetings bring together people with wide-ranging perspectives, interests, and expertise.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We also want to benefit from the insights of leading economic researchers.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We recently held a conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago that combined research presentations by top scholars with roundtable discussions among leaders of organizations that serve union workers, low- and moderate-income communities, small businesses, and people struggling to find work.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Scholars at the Chicago event offered a range of views on how well our monetary policy tools have effectively promoted our dual mandate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We learned more about cutting-edge ways to measure job market conditions.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We heard the latest perspectives on what financial and trade links with the rest of the world mean for the conduct of monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We heard scholarly views on the interplay between monetary policy and financial stability.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: And we heard a review of the clarity and the efficacy of our communications.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Like many others at the conference, I was particularly struck by two panels that included people who work every day in low- and middle-income communities.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: What we heard, loud and clear, was that today's tight labor markets mean that the benefits of this long recovery are now reaching these communities to a degree that has not been felt for many years.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We heard of companies, communities, and schools working together to bring employers the productive workers they need—and of employers working creatively to structure jobs so that employees can do their jobs while coping with the demands of family and life beyond the workplace.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We heard that many people who, in the past, struggled to stay in the workforce are now getting an opportunity to add new and better chapters to their life stories.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: All of this underscores how important it is to sustain this expansion.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The conference generated vibrant discussions.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We heard that we are doing many things well, that we have much we can improve, and that there are different views about which is which.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: That disagreement is neither surprising nor unwelcome.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The questions we are confronting about monetary policymaking and communication, particularly those relating to the ELB, are difficult ones that have grown in urgency over the past two decades.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: That is why it is so important that we actively seek opinions, ideas, and critiques from people throughout the economy to refine our understanding of how best to use the monetary policy powers Congress has granted us.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Beginning soon, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) will devote time at its regular meetings to assess the lessons from these events, supported by analysis by staff from around the Federal Reserve System.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We will publicly report the conclusions of our discussions, likely during the first half of next year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: In the meantime, anyone who is interested in learning more can find information on the Federal Reserve Board's website.1

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Let me turn now from the longer-term issues that are the focus of the review to the nearer-term outlook for the economy and for monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: So far this year, the economy has performed reasonably well.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Solid fundamentals are supporting continued growth and strong job creation, keeping the unemployment rate near historic lows.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Although inflation has been running somewhat below our symmetric 2 percent objective, we have expected it to pick up, supported by solid growth and a strong job market.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Along with this favorable picture, we have been mindful of some ongoing crosscurrents, including trade developments and concerns about global growth.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: When the FOMC met at the start of May, tentative evidence suggested these crosscurrents were moderating, and we saw no strong case for adjusting our policy rate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Since then, the picture has changed.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The crosscurrents have reemerged, with apparent progress on trade turning to greater uncertainty and with incoming data raising renewed concerns about the strength of the global economy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Our contacts in business and agriculture report heightened concerns over trade developments.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: These concerns may have contributed to the drop in business confidence in some recent surveys and may be starting to show through to incoming data.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: For example, the limited available evidence we have suggests that investment by businesses has slowed from the pace earlier in the year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Against the backdrop of heightened uncertainties, the baseline outlook of my FOMC colleagues, like that of many other forecasters, remains favorable, with unemployment remaining near historic lows.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Inflation is expected to return to 2 percent over time, but at a somewhat slower pace than we foresaw earlier in the year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: However, the risks to this favorable baseline outlook appear to have grown.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Last week, my FOMC colleagues and I held our regular meeting to assess the stance of monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We did not change the setting for our main policy tool, the target range for the federal funds rate, but we did make significant changes in our policy statement.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Since the beginning of the year, we had been taking a patient stance toward assessing the need for any policy change.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We now state that the Committee will closely monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: The question my colleagues and I are grappling with is whether these uncertainties will continue to weigh on the outlook and thus call for additional policy accommodation.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Many FOMC participants judge that the case for somewhat more accommodative policy has strengthened.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: But we are also mindful that monetary policy should not overreact to any individual data point or short-term swing in sentiment.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: Doing so would risk adding even more uncertainty to the outlook.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
text: We will closely monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today at the Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research, a place dedicated to scholarship supporting policies to better peoples' lives.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As today is International Women's Day, I would like to preface my remarks by commending the American Economic Association for highlighting the diversity challenges of the economics profession and charting a way forward.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Diversity is also a priority at the Fed: I want the Fed to be known within the economics profession as a great place for women, minorities, and others of diverse backgrounds to be respected, listened to, and happy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Just over 10 years ago, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC, or the Committee) lowered the federal funds rate close to zero, which we refer to as the effective lower bound, or ELB.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Unable to lower rates further, the Committee turned to two novel tools to promote the recovery.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The first was forward guidance, which is communication about the future path of interest rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The second was large-scale purchases of longer-term securities, which became known as quantitative easing, or QE.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: There is a range of views, but most studies have found that these tools provided significant support for the recovery.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: From the outset, the Committee viewed them as extraordinary measures to be unwound, or "normalized," when conditions ultimately warranted.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Today I will explore some important features of normalization and then turn to what comes after.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In some ways, we are returning to the pre-crisis normal.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In other ways, things will be different.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The world has moved on in the last decade, and attempting to re-create the past would be neither practical nor wise.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As normalization moves into its later stages, my colleagues and I also believe that this is an important moment to take stock of issues raised by the remarkable experiences of the past decade.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We are therefore conducting a review of the Fed's monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications practices.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: I will conclude with some thoughts on the review.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Balance Sheet NormalizationBetween December 2008 and October 2014, the Federal Reserve purchased $3.7 trillion in longer-term Treasury and agency securities in order to support the economy both by easing dislocations in market functioning and by driving down longer-term interest rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Consistent with the Committee's long-stated intention, in October 2017 we started the process of balance sheet normalization.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We began gradually reducing the reinvestment of payments received as assets matured or were prepaid, allowing our holdings to shrink.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The process of reducing the size of the portfolio is now well along.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: To frame the discussion of the final stages of normalization of the size of the balance sheet, it is useful to consider what the phrase "normal balance sheet" meant in the decades before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: During that period, the main monetary policy decision for the FOMC was choosing a target value for the federal funds rate.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Subject to that choice, the Fed allowed the demand for its liabilities to determine the size of the balance sheet.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: This is a feature of "normal" that we are returning to: After normalization, the size of the Fed's balance sheet will once again be driven by the demand for our liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: To see what this means, considerfigure 1, which shows the size of the Fed's balance sheet through time, as measured by total liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The values are stated as a percentage of the dollar value of GDP, or gross domestic product.1Liabilities began to grow sharply at the end of 2008 and continued to increase until the end of 2014.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Since that time, liabilities relative to GDP have fallen appreciably.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: To understand these changes, it is useful to focus on a snapshot of the balance sheet at three points in time: before the crisis, when the balance sheet was at its largest, and a rough projection for the end of this year (table 1).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In 2006, the dominant liability was currency held by the public, and the dominant asset was Treasury securities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The Fed's asset purchase programs increased the balance sheet from just below 6 percent to nearly 25 percent of GDP by the end of 2014.2Balance sheets must balance, of course, and the Fed issued reserves as payment for the assets purchased.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: This action pushed reserves to nearly 15 percent of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The Committee has long said that the size of the balance sheet will be considered normalized when the balance sheet is once again at the smallest level consistent with conducting monetary policy efficiently and effectively.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Just how large that will be is uncertain, because we do not yet have a clear sense of the normal level of demand for our liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Current estimates suggest, however, that something in the ballpark of the 2019:Q4 projected values may be the new normal.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The normalized balance sheet may be smaller or larger than that estimate and will grow gradually over time as demand for currency rises with the economy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In all plausible cases, the balance sheet will be considerably larger than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: To understand the differences between the new and old normal, consider the final column in the table, which shows the change, measured in percentage points of GDP, between 2006:Q4 and the 2019:Q4 projection in the table.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In this estimate, relative to before the crisis, the balance sheet will have grown as a share of GDP by about 10.6 percentage points.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Bank reserves account for the biggest part of the growth, or about 5.6 percent of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The crisis revealed that banks, especially the largest and most complex, faced much more liquidity risk than had previously been thought.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Because of both new liquidity regulations and improved management, banks now hold much higher levels of high-quality liquid assets than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Many banks choose to hold reserves as an important part of their strong liquidity positions.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The rest of the increase in liabilities is accounted for by three other categories.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: First, public currency holdings will have grown by 2.4 percentage points as a share of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Second, the U.S. Treasury maintains an account at the Fed, which has been running 1.4 percentage points higher as a share of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: And, third, other liabilities, which are mainly associated with the mechanics of the national and international financial system, will have grown by 1.1 percentage points.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As was the case before the crisis, the FOMC's chosen operating regime for controlling short-term interest rates also plays a role in determining the appropriate quantity of reserves.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In January, the Committee stated its intention to continue in our current regime in which our main policy rate, the federal funds rate or possibly some successor, is held within its target range by the interest rates we set on reserves and on the overnight reverse repo facility.3In this system, active management of the supply of reserves is not required.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Thus, the supply of reserves must be "ample," in the sense of being sufficient to satisfy reserve demands even in the face of volatility in factors affecting the reserve market.4Put another way, the quantity of reserves will equal the typical reserve demands of depositories plus a buffer to allow for reserve market fluctuations.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: While the precise level of reserves that will prove ample is uncertain, standard projections, such as those in the table, suggest we could be near that level later this year.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As we feel our way cautiously to this goal, we will move transparently and predictably in order to minimize needless market disruption and risks to our dual-mandate objectives.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The Committee is now well along in our discussions of a plan to conclude balance sheet runoff later this year.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Once balance sheet runoff ends, we may, if appropriate, hold the size of the balance sheet constant for a time to allow reserves to very gradually decline to the desired level as other liabilities, such as currency, increase.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We expect to announce further details of this plan reasonably soon.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: There is no real precedent for the balance sheet normalization process, and we have adapted our approach along the way.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In these final phases, we will adjust the details of our normalization plans if economic and financial conditions warrant.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: After decisions regarding the size of the balance sheet have been made, we will turn to remaining issues, such as the ultimate maturity composition of the portfolio.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The Committee has long stated that it intends to return to a portfolio consisting primarily of Treasury securities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Forward Guidance and the Normalization of Policy CommunicationThe Committee has also been normalizing communication about our policy after a decade of forward guidance.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Since December 2008, the FOMC's postmeeting statement had contained ever-evolving forms of guidance about keeping the federal funds rate at the ELB or about the gradual pace at which that rate would return to more normal levels.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We removed the last elements of this crisis-era guidance in January.5The federal funds rate is now within the broad range of estimates of the neutral rate--the interest rate that tends neither to stimulate nor to restrain the economy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Committee participants generally agree that this policy stance is appropriate to promote our dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Future adjustments will depend on what incoming data tell us about the baseline outlook and risks to that outlook.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Policy communication will not simply revert to the ways of the early 2000s, however, for transparency advances have continued apace since then.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The most significant change from the standpoint of forward guidance is that, since January 2012, the FOMC's quarterly Summary of Economic Projections (SEP) has included federal funds rate projections reaching up to three years into the future--often referred to as the "dot plot."

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Returning to a world of little or no explicit forward guidance in the FOMC's postmeeting statement presents a challenge, for the dot plot has, on occasion, been a source of confusion.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Until now, forward guidance in the statement has been a main tool for communicating committee intentions and minimizing that confusion.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: For example, in early 2014, the Committee's intentions were at odds with a common misreading of the dots, and Chair Yellen explained, "[O]ne should not look to the dot plot, so to speak, as the primary way in which the Committee wants to or is speaking about policy to the public at large.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The FOMC statement is the device that the Committee as a policymaking group uses to express its opinions .

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: about the likely path of rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: "6If the Committee remains largely out of the business of explicit forward guidance, we will need to find other ways to address the collateral confusion that sometimes surrounds the dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As readers of the FOMC minutes will know, at our last meeting in January there was an impromptu discussion among some participants of general concerns about the dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: My own view is that, if properly understood, the dot plot can be a constructive element of comprehensive policy communication.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Let me follow my two predecessors as Chair in attempting to advance that proper understanding.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Each participant's dots reflect that participant's view of the policy that would be appropriate in the scenario that he or she sees as most likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As someone who has filled out an SEP projection 27 times over the last seven years, I can say that there are times when I feel that something like the "most likely" scenario I write down is, indeed, reasonably likely to happen.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: At other times, when uncertainty around the outlook is unusually high, I dutifully write down what I see as the appropriate funds rate path in the most likely scenario, but I do so aware that this projection may be easily misinterpreted, for what is "most likely" may not be particularly likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Very different scenarios may be similarly likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Further, at times downside risks may deserve significant weight in policy deliberations.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In short, as Chairman Bernanke explained, the SEP projections are merely "inputs" to policy that do not convey "the risks, the uncertainties, all the things that inform our collective judgment.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Effectively conveying our views about risks and their role in policy projections can be challenging at times, and we are always looking for ways to improve our communications.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: I have asked the communications subcommittee of the FOMC to explore ways in which we can more effectively communicate about the role of the rate projections.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: For now, let me leave you with a cautionary tale about focusing too much on dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Here is a picture composed of different colored dots (figure 2).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The meaning of it is not clear, although if you stare at it long enough you might see a pattern.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: But let's take a step back (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: As you can see, if you are too focused on a few dots, you may miss the larger picture.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Delivering on the FOMC's intention to ultimately normalize policy continues to be a major priority at the Fed.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Normalization is far along, and, considering the unprecedented nature of the exercise, it is proceeding smoothly.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: I am confident that we can effectively manage the remaining stages.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Beyond NormalizationWe live in a time of intense scrutiny and declining trust in public institutions around the world.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: At the Fed, we are committed to working hard to build and sustain the public's trust.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The Fed has special responsibilities in this regard.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Our monetary policy independence allows us to serve the public without regard to short-term political considerations, which, as history has shown, is critical for sound monetary policymaking.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: But that precious grant of independence brings with it a special obligation to be open and transparent, welcoming scrutiny by the public and their elected representatives in Congress.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Only in this way can the Fed maintain its legitimacy in our democratic system.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Among other initiatives, my colleagues and I on the FOMC are undertaking a year-long review of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy strategy, tools, and communication practices.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The review will involve a series of "Fed Listens" events around the country.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: These will include town-hall-style meetings and a conference where academic and nonacademic experts will share their views.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: These events will inform staff work and FOMC discussions as we plan for the future.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: While this is the first time the Fed has opened itself up in this way, many central banks around the world have conducted similar reviews, and our approach builds on their experiences.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We believe that our existing framework for conducting monetary policy has generally served the public well, and the review may or may not produce major changes.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Consistent with the experience of other central banks with these reviews, the process is more likely to produce evolution rather than revolution.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: We seek no changes in law and we are not considering fundamental changes in the structure of the Fed, or in the 2 percent inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: While there is a high bar for adopting fundamental change, it simply seems like good institutional practice to engage broadly with the public as part of a comprehensive approach to enhanced transparency and accountability.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Without ruling out other topics, we have highlighted three questions that seem particularly important at present (figure 4):

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Can the Federal Reserve best meet its statutory objectives with its existing monetary policy strategy, or should it consider strategies that aim to reverse past misses of the inflation objective?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Are the existing monetary policy tools adequate to achieve and maintain maximum employment and price stability, or should the toolkit be expanded?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: How can the FOMC's communication of its policy framework and implementation be improved?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: I would like to spend a few minutes discussing the first topic.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Because interest rates around the world have steadily declined for several decades, rates in normal times now tend to be much closer to zero than in the past (figure 5).8Thus, when a recession comes, the Fed is likely to have less capacity to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy than in the past, suggesting that trips to the ELB may be more frequent.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: The post-crisis period has seen many economies around the world stuck for an extended period at the ELB, with slow growth and inflation well below target.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Persistently weak inflation could lead inflation expectations to drift downward, which would imply still lower interest rates, leaving even less room for central banks to cut interest rates to support the economy during a downturn.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: It is therefore very important for central banks to find more effective ways to battle the low-inflation syndrome that seems to accompany proximity to the ELB.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In the late 1990s, motivated by the Japanese experience with deflation and sluggish economic performance, economists began developing the argument that a central bank might substantially reduce the economic costs of ELB spells by adopting a makeup strategy.9The simplest version goes like this: If a spell with interest rates near the ELB leads to a persistent shortfall of inflation relative to the central bank's goal, once the ELB spell ends, the central bank would deliberately make up for the lost inflation by stimulating the economy and temporarily pushing inflation modestly above the target.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In standard macroeconomic models, if households and businesses are confident that this future inflationary stimulus will be coming, that prospect will promote anticipatory consumption and investment.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: This can substantially reduce the economic costs of ELB spells.10Researchers have suggested many variations on makeup strategies.11For example, the central bank could target average inflation over time, implying that misses on either side of the target would be offset.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: By the time of the crisis, there was a well-established body of model-based research suggesting that some kind of makeup policy could be beneficial.12In light of this research, one might ask why the Fed and other major central banks chose not to pursue such a policy.13The answer lies in the uncertain distance between models and reality.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: For makeup strategies to achieve their stabilizing benefits, households and businesses must be quite confident that the "makeup stimulus" is really coming.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: This confidence is what prompts them to raise spending and investment in the midst of a downturn.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In models, confidence in the policy is merely an assumption.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In practice, when policymakers considered these policies in the wake of the crisis, they had major questions about whether a central bank's promise of good times to come would have moved the hearts, minds, and pocketbooks of the public.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Part of the problem is that when the time comes to deliver the inflationary stimulus, that policy is likely to be unpopular--what is known as the time consistency problem in economics.14

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Experience in the United States and around the world suggests that more frequent ELB episodes could prove quite costly in the future.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: My FOMC colleagues and I believe that we have a responsibility to the American people to consider policies that might promote significantly better economic outcomes.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Makeup strategies are probably the most prominent idea and deserve serious attention.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: They are largely untried, however, and we have reason to question how they would perform in practice.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Before they could be successfully implemented, there would have to be widespread societal understanding and acceptance--as I suggested, a high bar for any fundamental change.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: In this review, we seek to start a discussion about makeup strategies and other policies that might broadly benefit the American people.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: ConclusionTonight I have focused on policy normalization and our efforts to engage the public in what may come after.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Before concluding, I will say a few words on current conditions and the outlook.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Right now, most measures of the health and strength of the labor market look as favorable as they have in many decades.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Inflation will probably run a bit below our objective for a time due to declines in energy prices, but those effects are likely to prove transitory.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Core inflation, which is often a reliable indicator of where inflation is headed over time, is quite close to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Despite this favorable picture, we have seen some cross-currents in recent months.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: With nothing in the outlook demanding an immediate policy response and particularly given muted inflation pressures, the Committee has adopted a patient, wait-and-see approach to considering any alteration in the stance of policy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Considering monetary policy more broadly, we are inviting thorough public scrutiny and are hoping to foster conversation regarding how the Fed can best exercise the precious monetary policy independence we have been granted.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
text: Our goal is to enhance the public's trust in the Federal Reserve--our most valuable asset.
