title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Thank you, Esther, for that introduction, and good morning.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The Kansas City Fed's Economic Policy Symposiums have consistently served as a vital platform for discussing the most challenging economic issues of the day.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Judging by the agenda and the papers, this year will be no exception.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: For the past year and a half, my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) have been conducting the first-ever public review of our monetary policy framework.1Earlier today we released a revised Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, a document that lays out our goals, articulates our framework for monetary policy, and serves as the foundation for our policy actions.2Today I will discuss our review, the changes in the economy that motivated us to undertake it, and our revised statement, which encapsulates the main conclusions of the review.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Evolution of the Fed's Monetary Policy FrameworkWe began this public review in early 2019 to assess the monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications that would best foster achievement of our congressionally assigned goals of maximum employment and price stability over the years ahead in service to the American people.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Because the economy is always evolving, the FOMC's strategy for achieving its goals—our policy framework—must adapt to meet the new challenges that arise.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Forty years ago, the biggest problem our economy faced was high and rising inflation.3The Great Inflation demanded a clear focus on restoring the credibility of the FOMC's commitment to price stability.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Chair Paul Volcker brought that focus to bear, and the "Volcker disinflation," with the continuing stewardship of Alan Greenspan, led to the stabilization of inflation and inflation expectations in the 1990s at around 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The monetary policies of the Volcker era laid the foundation for the long period of economic stability known as the Great Moderation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This new era brought new challenges to the conduct of monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Before the Great Moderation, expansions typically ended in overheating and rising inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Since then, prior to the current pandemic-induced downturn, a series of historically long expansions had been more likely to end with episodes of financial instability, prompting essential efforts to substantially increase the strength and resilience of the financial system.4

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: By the early 2000s, many central banks around the world had adopted a monetary policy framework known as inflation targeting.5Although the precise features of inflation targeting differed from country to country, the core framework always articulated an inflation goal as a primary objective of monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Inflation targeting was also associated with increased communication and transparency designed to clarify the central bank's policy intentions.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This emphasis on transparency reflected what was then a new appreciation that policy is most effective when it is clearly understood by the public.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Inflation-targeting central banks generally do not focus solely on inflation: Those with "flexible" inflation targets take into account economic stabilization in addition to their inflation objective.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Under Ben Bernanke's leadership, the Federal Reserve adopted many of the features associated with flexible inflation targeting.6We made great advances in transparency and communications, with the initiation of quarterly press conferences and the Summary of Economic Projections (SEP), which comprises the individual economic forecasts of FOMC participants.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: During that time, then–Board Vice Chair Janet Yellen led an effort on behalf of the FOMC to codify the Committee's approach to monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In January 2012, the Committee issued its first Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, which we often refer to as the consensus statement.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: A central part of this statement was the articulation of a longer-run inflation goal of 2 percent.7Because the structure of the labor market is strongly influenced by nonmonetary factors that can change over time, the Committee did not set a numerical objective for maximum employment.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: However, the statement affirmed the Committee's commitment to fulfilling both of its congressionally mandated goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The 2012 statement was a significant milestone, reflecting lessons learned from fighting high inflation as well as from experience around the world with flexible inflation targeting.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The statement largely articulated the policy framework the Committee had been following for some time.8

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Motivation for the ReviewThe completion of the original consensus statement in January 2012 occurred early on in the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis, when notions of what the "new normal" might bring were quite uncertain.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Since then, our understanding of the economy has evolved in ways that are central to monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Of course, the conduct of monetary policy has also evolved.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: A key purpose of our review has been to take stock of the lessons learned over this period and identify any further changes in our monetary policy framework that could enhance our ability to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability objectives in the years ahead.9

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our evolving understanding of four key economic developments motivated our review.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: First, assessments of the potential, or longer-run, growth rate of the economy have declined.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: For example, since January 2012, the median estimate of potential growth from FOMC participants has fallen from 2.5 percent to 1.8 percent (seefigure 1).

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Some slowing in growth relative to earlier decades was to be expected, reflecting slowing population growth and the aging of the population.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: More troubling has been the decline in productivity growth, which is the primary driver of improving living standards over time.10

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Second, the general level of interest rates has fallen both here in the United States and around the world.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Estimates of the neutral federal funds rate, which is the rate consistent with the economy operating at full strength and with stable inflation, have fallen substantially, in large part reflecting a fall in the equilibrium real interest rate, or "r-star."

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This rate is not affected by monetary policy but instead is driven by fundamental factors in the economy, including demographics and productivity growth—the same factors that drive potential economic growth.11The median estimate from FOMC participants of the neutral federal funds rate has fallen by nearly half since early 2012, from 4.25 percent to 2.5 percent (seefigure 2).

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This decline in assessments of the neutral federal funds rate has profound implications for monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: With interest rates generally running closer to their effective lower bound even in good times, the Fed has less scope to support the economy during an economic downturn by simply cutting the federal funds rate.12The result can be worse economic outcomes in terms of both employment and price stability, with the costs of such outcomes likely falling hardest on those least able to bear them.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Third, and on a happier note, the record-long expansion that ended earlier this year led to the best labor market we had seen in some time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The unemployment rate hovered near 50-year lows for roughly 2 years, well below most estimates of its sustainable level.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: And the unemployment rate captures only part of the story.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Having declined significantly in the five years following the crisis, the labor force participation rate flattened out and began rising even though the aging of the population suggested that it should keep falling.13For individuals in their prime working years, the participation rate fully retraced its post-crisis decline, defying earlier assessments that the Global Financial Crisis might cause permanent structural damage to the labor market.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Moreover, as the long expansion continued, the gains began to be shared more widely across society.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The Black and Hispanic unemployment rates reached record lows, and the differentials between these rates and the white unemployment rate narrowed to their lowest levels on record.14As we heard repeatedly in ourFed Listensevents, the robust job market was delivering life-changing gains for many individuals, families, and communities, particularly at the lower end of the income spectrum.15In addition, many who had been left behind for too long were finding jobs, benefiting their families and communities, and increasing the productive capacity of our economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Before the pandemic, there was every reason to expect that these gains would continue.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: It is hard to overstate the benefits of sustaining a strong labor market, a key national goal that will require a range of policies in addition to supportive monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Fourth, the historically strong labor market did not trigger a significant rise in inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Over the years, forecasts from FOMC participants and private-sector analysts routinely showed a return to 2 percent inflation, but these forecasts were never realized on a sustained basis (seefigure 3).

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Inflation forecasts are typically predicated on estimates of the natural rate of unemployment, or "u-star," and of how much upward pressure on inflation arises when the unemployment rate falls relative to u-star.16As the unemployment rate moved lower and inflation remained muted, estimates of u-star were revised down.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: For example, the median estimate from FOMC participants declined from 5.5 percent in 2012 to 4.1 percent at present (seefigure 4).

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The muted responsiveness of inflation to labor market tightness, which we refer to as the flattening of the Phillips curve, also contributed to low inflation outcomes.17In addition, longer-term inflation expectations, which we have long seen as an important driver of actual inflation, and global disinflationary pressures may have been holding down inflation more than was generally anticipated.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Other advanced economies have also struggled to achieve their inflation goals in recent decades.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The persistent undershoot of inflation from our 2 percent longer-run objective is a cause for concern.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Many find it counterintuitive that the Fed would want to push up inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: After all, low and stable inflation is essential for a well-functioning economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: And we are certainly mindful that higher prices for essential items, such as food, gasoline, and shelter, add to the burdens faced by many families, especially those struggling with lost jobs and incomes.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: However, inflation that is persistently too low can pose serious risks to the economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Inflation that runs below its desired level can lead to an unwelcome fall in longer-term inflation expectations, which, in turn, can pull actual inflation even lower, resulting in an adverse cycle of ever-lower inflation and inflation expectations.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This dynamic is a problem because expected inflation feeds directly into the general level of interest rates.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Well-anchored inflation expectations are critical for giving the Fed the latitude to support employment when necessary without destabilizing inflation.18But if inflation expectations fall below our 2 percent objective, interest rates would decline in tandem.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In turn, we would have less scope to cut interest rates to boost employment during an economic downturn, further diminishing our capacity to stabilize the economy through cutting interest rates.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: We have seen this adverse dynamic play out in other major economies around the world and have learned that once it sets in, it can be very difficult to overcome.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: We want to do what we can to prevent such a dynamic from happening here.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Elements of the ReviewWe began our review with these changes in the economy in mind.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The review had three pillars: a series ofFed Listensevents held around the country, a flagship research conference, and a series of Committee discussions supported by rigorous staff analysis.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: As is appropriate in our democratic society, we have sought extensive engagement with the public throughout the review.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: TheFed Listensevents built on a long-standing practice around the Federal Reserve System of engaging with community groups.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The 15 events involved a wide range of participants—workforce development groups, union members, small business owners, residents of low- and moderate-income communities, retirees, and others—to hear about how our policies affect peoples' daily lives and livelihoods.19The stories we heard atFed Listensevents became a potent vehicle for us to connect with the people and communities that our policies are intended to benefit.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: One of the clear messages we heard was that the strong labor market that prevailed before the pandemic was generating employment opportunities for many Americans who in the past had not found jobs readily available.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: A clear takeaway from these events was the importance of achieving and sustaining a strong job market, particularly for people from low- and moderate-income communities.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The research conference brought together some of the world's leading academic experts to address topics central to our review, and the presentations and robust discussion we engaged in were an important input to our review process.20

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Finally, the Committee explored the range of issues that were brought to light during the course of the review in five consecutive meetings beginning in July 2019.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Analytical staff work put together by teams across the Federal Reserve System provided essential background for each of the Committee's discussions.21

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our plans to conclude the review earlier this year were, like so many things, delayed by the arrival of the pandemic.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: When we resumed our discussions last month, we turned our attention to distilling the most important lessons of the review in a revised Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: New Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy StrategyThe federated structure of the Federal Reserve, reflected in the FOMC, ensures that we always have a diverse range of perspectives on monetary policy, and that is certainly the case today.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Nonetheless, I am pleased to say that the revised consensus statement was adopted today with the unanimous support of Committee participants.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our new consensus statement, like its predecessor, explains how we interpret the mandate Congress has given us and describes the broad framework that we believe will best promote our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Before addressing the key changes in our statement, let me highlight some areas of continuity.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: We continue to believe that specifying a numerical goal for employment is unwise, because the maximum level of employment is not directly measurable and changes over time for reasons unrelated to monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The significant shifts in estimates of the natural rate of unemployment over the past decade reinforce this point.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In addition, we have not changed our view that a longer-run inflation rate of 2 percent is most consistent with our mandate to promote both maximum employment and price stability.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Finally, we continue to believe that monetary policy must be forward looking, taking into account the expectations of households and businesses and the lags in monetary policy's effect on the economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Thus, our policy actions continue to depend on the economic outlook as well as the risks to the outlook, including potential risks to the financial system that could impede the attainment of our goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The key innovations in our new consensus statement reflect the changes in the economy I described.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our new statement explicitly acknowledges the challenges posed by the proximity of interest rates to the effective lower bound.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: By reducing our scope to support the economy by cutting interest rates, the lower bound increases downward risks to employment and inflation.22To counter these risks, we are prepared to use our full range of tools to support the economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: With regard to the employment side of our mandate, our revised statement emphasizes that maximum employment is a broad-based and inclusive goal.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: This change reflects our appreciation for the benefits of a strong labor market, particularly for many in low- and moderate-income communities.23In addition, our revised statement says that our policy decision will be informed by our "assessments of theshortfallsof employment from its maximum level" rather than by "deviationsfrom its maximum level" as in our previous statement.24This change may appear subtle, but it reflects our view that a robust job market can be sustained without causing an outbreak of inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In earlier decades when the Phillips curve was steeper, inflation tended to rise noticeably in response to a strengthening labor market.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: It was sometimes appropriate for the Fed to tighten monetary policy as employment rose toward its estimated maximum level in order to stave off an unwelcome rise in inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The change to "shortfalls" clarifies that, going forward, employment can run at or above real-time estimates of its maximum level without causing concern, unless accompanied by signs of unwanted increases in inflation or the emergence of other risks that could impede the attainment of our goals.25Of course, when employment is below its maximum level, as is clearly the case now, we will actively seek to minimize that shortfall by using our tools to support economic growth and job creation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: We have also made important changes with regard to the price-stability side of our mandate.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our longer-run goal continues to be an inflation rate of 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Our statement emphasizes that our actions to achieve both sides of our dual mandate will be most effective if longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: However, if inflation runs below 2 percent following economic downturns but never moves above 2 percent even when the economy is strong, then, over time, inflation will average less than 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Households and businesses will come to expect this result, meaning that inflation expectations would tend to move below our inflation goal and pull realized inflation down.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: To prevent this outcome and the adverse dynamics that could ensue, our new statement indicates that we will seek to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Therefore, following periods when inflation has been running below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In seeking to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time, we are not tying ourselves to a particular mathematical formula that defines the average.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Thus, our approach could be viewed as a flexible form of average inflation targeting.26Our decisions about appropriate monetary policy will continue to reflect a broad array of considerations and will not be dictated by any formula.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Of course, if excessive inflationary pressures were to build or inflation expectations were to ratchet above levels consistent with our goal, we would not hesitate to act.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: The revisions to our statement add up to a robust updating of our monetary policy framework.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: To an extent, these revisions reflect the way we have been conducting policy in recent years.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: At the same time, however, there are some important new features.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Overall, our new Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy conveys our continued strong commitment to achieving our goals, given the difficult challenges presented by the proximity of interest rates to the effective lower bound.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: In conducting monetary policy, we will remain highly focused on fostering as strong a labor market as possible for the benefit of all Americans.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: And we will steadfastly seek to achieve a 2 percent inflation rate over time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: Looking AheadOur review has provided a platform for productive discussion and engagement with the public we serve.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: TheFed Listensevents helped us connect with our core constituency, the American people, and hear directly how their everyday lives are affected by our policies.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: We believe that conducting a review at regular intervals is a good institutional practice, providing valuable feedback and enhancing transparency and accountability.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: And with the ever-changing economy, future reviews will allow us to take a step back, reflect on what we have learned, and adapt our practices as we strive to achieve our dual-mandate goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
text: As our statement indicates, we plan to undertake a thorough public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communication practices roughly every five years.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Seventeen months have passed since the U.S. economy faced the full force of the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: This shock led to an immediate and unprecedented decline as large parts of the economy were shuttered to contain the spread of the disease.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The path of recovery has been a difficult one, and a good place to begin is by thanking those on the front line fighting the pandemic: the essential workers who kept the economy going, those who have cared for others in need, and those in medical research, business, and government, who came together to discover, produce, and widely distribute effective vaccines in record time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We should also keep in our thoughts those who have lost their lives from COVID, as well as their loved ones.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Strong policy support has fueled a vigorous but uneven recovery—one that is, in many respects, historically anomalous.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: In a reversal of typical patterns in a downturn, aggregate personal income rose rather than fell, and households massively shifted their spending from services to manufactured goods.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Booming demand for goods and the strength and speed of the reopening have led to shortages and bottlenecks, leaving the COVID-constrained supply side unable to keep up.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The result has been elevated inflation in durable goods—a sector that has experienced an annual inflation rate well below zero over the past quarter century.1Labor market conditions are improving but turbulent, and the pandemic continues to threaten not only health and life, but also economic activity.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Many other advanced economies are experiencing similarly unusual conditions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: In my comments today, I will focus on the Fed's efforts to promote our maximum employment and price stability goals amid this upheaval, and suggest how lessons from history and a careful focus on incoming data and the evolving risks offer useful guidance for today's unique monetary policy challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The Recession and Recovery So FarThe pandemic recession—the briefest yet deepest on record—displaced roughly 30 million workers in the space of two months.2The decline in output in the second quarter of 2020 was twice the full decline during the Great Recession of 2007–09.3But the pace of the recovery has exceeded expectations, with output surpassing its previous peak after only four quarters, less than half the time required following the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: As is typically the case, the recovery in employment has lagged that in output; nonetheless, employment gains have also come faster than expected.4

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: In particular, despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on lower-wage workers in the service sector and on African Americans and Hispanics.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The unevenness of the recovery can further be seen through the lens of the sectoral shift of spending into goods—particularly durable goods such as appliances, furniture, and cars—and away from services, particularly in-person services in areas such as travel and leisure (figure 1).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: As the pandemic struck, restaurant meals fell 45 percent, air travel 95 percent, and dentist visits 65 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Even today, with overall gross domestic product and consumption spending more than fully recovered, services spending remains about 7 percent below trend.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Total employment is now 6 million below its February 2020 level, and 5 million of that shortfall is in the still-depressed service sector.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: In contrast, spending on durable goods has boomed since the start of the recovery and is now running about 20 percent above the pre-pandemic level.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: With demand outstripping pandemic-afflicted supply, rising durables prices are a principal factor lifting inflation well above our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Given the ongoing upheaval in the economy, some strains and surprises are inevitable.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The job of monetary policy is to promote maximum employment and price stability as the economy works through this challenging period.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: I will turn now to a discussion of progress toward those goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The Path Ahead: Maximum EmploymentThe outlook for the labor market has brightened considerably in recent months.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: After faltering last winter, job gains have risen steadily over the course of this year and now average 832,000 over the past three months, of which almost 800,000 have been in services (figure 2).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The pace of total hiring is faster than at any time in the recorded data before the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The levels of job openings and quits are at record highs, and employers report that they cannot fill jobs fast enough to meet returning demand.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These favorable conditions for job seekers should help the economy cover the considerable remaining ground to reach maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The unemployment rate has declined to 5.4 percent, a post-pandemic low, but is still much too high, and the reported rate understates the amount of labor market slack.5Long-term unemployment remains elevated, and the recovery in labor force participation has lagged well behind the rest of the labor market, as it has in past recoveries.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: With vaccinations rising, schools reopening, and enhanced unemployment benefits ending, some factors that may be holding back job seekers are likely fading.6While the Delta variant presents a near-term risk, the prospects are good for continued progress toward maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The Path Ahead: InflationThe rapid reopening of the economy has brought a sharp run-up in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Over the 12 months through July, measures of headline and core personal consumption expenditures inflation have run at 4.2 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively—well above our 2 percent longer-run objective.7Businesses and consumers widely report upward pressure on prices and wages.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Inflation at these levels is, of course, a cause for concern.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: But that concern is tempered by a number of factors that suggest that these elevated readings are likely to prove temporary.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: This assessment is a critical and ongoing one, and we are carefully monitoring incoming data.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The dynamics of inflation are complex, and we assess the inflation outlook from a number of different perspectives, as I will now discuss.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The absence so far of broad-based inflation pressuresThe spike in inflation is so far largely the product of a relatively narrow group of goods and services that have been directly affected by the pandemic and the reopening of the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Durable goods alone contributed about 1 percentage point to the latest 12‑month measures of headline and core inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Energy prices, which rebounded with the strong recovery, added another 0.8 percentage point to headline inflation, and from long experience we expect the inflation effects of these increases to be transitory.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: In addition, some prices—for example, for hotel rooms and airplane tickets—declined sharply during the recession and have now moved back up close to pre-pandemic levels.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The 12-month window we use in computing inflation now captures the rebound in prices but not the initial decline, temporarily elevating reported inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These effects, which are adding a few tenths to measured inflation, should wash out over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We consult a range of measures meant to capture whether price increases for particular items are spilling over into broad-based inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These include trimmed mean measures and measures excluding durables and computed from just before the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These measures generally show inflation at or close to our 2 percent longer-run objective (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We would be concerned at signs that inflationary pressures were spreading more broadly through the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Moderating inflation in higher-inflation itemsWe are also directly monitoring the prices of particular goods and services most affected by the pandemic and the reopening, and are beginning to see a moderation in some cases as shortages ease.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Used car prices, for example, appear to have stabilized; indeed, some price indicators are beginning to fall.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: If that continues, as many analysts predict, then used car prices will soon be pulling measured inflation down, as they did for much of the past decade.8

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: This same dynamic of upward inflation pressure dissipating and, in some cases, reversing seems likely to play out in durables more generally.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Over the 25 years preceding the pandemic, durables prices actually declined, with inflation averaging negative 1.9 percent per year (figure 5).9As supply problems have begun to resolve, inflation in durable goods other than autos has now slowed and may be starting to fall.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: It seems unlikely that durables inflation will continue to contribute importantly over time to overall inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We will be looking for evidence that supports or undercuts that expectation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: WagesWe also assess whether wage increases are consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Wage increases are essential to support a rising standard of living and are generally, of course, a welcome development.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: But if wage increases were to move materially and persistently above the levels of productivity gains and inflation, businesses would likely pass those increases on to customers, a process that could become the sort of "wage–price spiral" seen at times in the past.10Today we see little evidence of wage increases that might threaten excessive inflation (figure 6).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Broad-based measures of wages that adjust for compositional changes in the labor force, such as the employment cost index and the Atlanta Wage Growth Tracker, show wages moving up at a pace that appears consistent with our longer-term inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We will continue to monitor this carefully.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Longer-term inflation expectationsPolicymakers and analysts generally believe that, as long as longer-term inflation expectations remain anchored, policy can and should look through temporary swings in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Our monetary policy framework emphasizes that anchoring longer-term expectations at 2 percent is important for both maximum employment and price stability.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We carefully monitor a wide range of indicators of longer-term inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These measures today are at levels broadly consistent with our 2 percent objective (figure 4).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Because measures of inflation expectations are individually noisy, we also focus on common patterns across the measures.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: One approach to summarizing these patterns is the Board staff's index of common inflation expectations (CIE), which combines information from a broad range of survey and market-based measures.11This index captures a general move down in expectations starting around 2014, a time when inflation was running persistently below 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: More recently, the index shows a welcome reversal of that decline and is now at levels more consistent with our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Longer-term inflation expectations have moved much less than actual inflation or near-term expectations, suggesting that households, businesses, and market participants also believe that current high inflation readings are likely to prove transitory and that, in any case, the Fed will keep inflation close to our 2 percent objective over time.12

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The prevalence of global disinflationary forces over the past quarter centuryFinally, it is worth noting that, since the 1990s, inflation in many advanced economies has run somewhat below 2 percent even in good times (figure 7).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The pattern of low inflation likely reflects sustained disinflationary forces, including technology, globalization and perhaps demographic factors, as well as a stronger and more successful commitment by central banks to maintain price stability.13In the United States, unemployment ran below 4 percent for about two years before the pandemic, while inflation ran at or below 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Wages did move up across the income spectrum—a welcome development—but not by enough to lift price inflation consistently to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: While the underlying global disinflationary factors are likely to evolve over time, there is little reason to think that they have suddenly reversed or abated.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: It seems more likely that they will continue to weigh on inflation as the pandemic passes into history.14

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We will continue to monitor incoming inflation data against each of these assessments.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: To sum up, the baseline outlook is for continued progress toward maximum employment, with inflation returning to levels consistent with our goal of inflation averaging 2 percent over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Let me now turn to how the baseline outlook and the associated risks and uncertainties figure in our monetary policymaking.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Implications for Monetary PolicyThe period from 1950 through the early 1980s provides two important lessons for managing the risks and uncertainties we face today.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The early days of stabilization policy in the 1950s taught monetary policymakers not to attempt to offset what are likely to be temporary fluctuations in inflation.15Indeed, responding may do more harm than good, particularly in an era where policy rates are much closer to the effective lower bound even in good times.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The main influence of monetary policy on inflation can come after a lag of a year or more.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: If a central bank tightens policy in response to factors that turn out to be temporary, the main policy effects are likely to arrive after the need has passed.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The ill-timed policy move unnecessarily slows hiring and other economic activity and pushes inflation lower than desired.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Today, with substantial slack remaining in the labor market and the pandemic continuing, such a mistake could be particularly harmful.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We know that extended periods of unemployment can mean lasting harm to workers and to the productive capacity of the economy.16

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: History also teaches, however, that central banks cannot take for granted that inflation due to transitory factors will fade.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The 1970s saw two periods in which there were large increases in energy and food prices, raising headline inflation for a time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: But when the direct effects on headline inflation eased, core inflation continued to run persistently higher than before.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: One likely contributing factor was that the public had come to generally expect higher inflation—one reason why we now monitor inflation expectations so carefully.17

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Central banks have always faced the problem of distinguishing transitory inflation spikes from more troublesome developments, and it is sometimes difficult to do so with confidence in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: At such times, there is no substitute for a careful focus on incoming data and evolving risks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: If sustained higher inflation were to become a serious concern, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) would certainly respond and use our tools to assure that inflation runs at levels that are consistent with our goal.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Incoming data should provide more evidence that some of the supply–demand imbalances are improving, and more evidence of a continued moderation in inflation, particularly in goods and services prices that have been most affected by the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We also expect to see continued strong job creation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: And we will be learning more about the Delta variant's effects.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: For now, I believe that policy is well positioned; as always, we are prepared to adjust policy as appropriate to achieve our goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: That brings me to a concluding word on the path ahead for monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The Committee remains steadfast in our oft-expressed commitment to support the economy for as long as is needed to achieve a full recovery.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The changes we made last year to our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy are well suited to address today's challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We have said that we would continue our asset purchases at the current pace until we see substantial further progress toward our maximum employment and price stability goals, measured since last December, when we first articulated this guidance.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: My view is that the "substantial further progress" test has been met for inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: There has also been clear progress toward maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: At the FOMC's recent July meeting, I was of the view, as were most participants, that if the economy evolved broadly as anticipated, it could be appropriate to start reducing the pace of asset purchases this year.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The intervening month has brought more progress in the form of a strong employment report for July, but also the further spread of the Delta variant.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We will be carefully assessing incoming data and the evolving risks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Even after our asset purchases end, our elevated holdings of longer-term securities will continue to support accommodative financial conditions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: The timing and pace of the coming reduction in asset purchases will not be intended to carry a direct signal regarding the timing of interest rate liftoff, for which we have articulated a different and substantially more stringent test.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We have said that we will continue to hold the target range for the federal funds rate at its current level until the economy reaches conditions consistent with maximum employment, and inflation has reached 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: We have much ground to cover to reach maximum employment, and time will tell whether we have reached 2 percent inflation on a sustainable basis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: These are challenging times for the public we serve, as the pandemic and its unprecedented toll on health and economic activity linger.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: But I will end on a positive note.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Before the pandemic, we all saw the extraordinary benefits that a strong labor market can deliver to our society.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
text: Despite today's challenges, the economy is on a path to just such a labor market, with high levels of employment and participation, broadly shared wage gains, and inflation running close to our price stability goal.
