title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Today I will discuss the state of our labor market, from the recent past to the present and then over the longer term.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: A strong labor market that is sustained for an extended period can deliver substantial economic and social benefits, including higher employment and income levels, improved and expanded job opportunities, narrower economic disparities, and healing of the entrenched damage inflicted by past recessions on individuals' economic and personal well-being.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At present, we are a long way from such a labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Fully realizing the benefits of a strong labor market will take continued support from both near-term policy and longer-run investments so that all those seeking jobs have the skills and opportunities that will enable them to contribute to, and share in, the benefits of prosperity.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The Labor Market of a Year AgoWe need only look to February of last year to see how beneficial a strong labor market can be.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The overall unemployment rate was 3.5 percent, the lowest level in a half-century.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The unemployment rate for African Americans had also reached historical lows (figure 1).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Prime-age labor force participation was the highest in over a decade, and a high proportion of households saw jobs as "plentiful.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: "1Overall wage growth was moderate, but wages were rising more rapidly for earners on the lower end of the scale.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: These encouraging statistics were reaffirmed and given voice by those we met and conferred with, including the community, labor, and business leaders; retirees; students; and others we met with during the 14Fed Listensevents we conducted in 2019.2

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Many of these gains had emerged only in the later years of the expansion.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The labor force participation rate, for example, had been steadily declining from 2008 to 2015 even as the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis unfolded.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In fact, in 2015, prime-age labor force participation—which I focus on because it is not significantly affected by the aging of the population—reached its lowest level in 30 years even as the unemployment rate declined to a relatively low 5 percent.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Also concerning was that much of the decline in participation up to that point had been concentrated in the population without a college degree (figure 2).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At the time, many forecasters worried that globalization and technological change might have permanently reduced job opportunities for these individuals, and that, as a result, there might be limited scope for participation to recover.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Fortunately, the participation rate after 2015 consistently outperformed expectations, and by the beginning of 2020, the prime-age participation rate had fully reversed its decline from the 2008-to-2015 period.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Moreover, gains in participation were concentrated among people without a college degree.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Given that U.S. labor force participation has lagged relative to other advanced economy nations, this progress was especially welcome (figure 3).3

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: As I mentioned, we also saw faster wage growth for low earners once the labor market had strengthened sufficiently.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Nearly six years into the recovery, wage growth for the lowest earning quartile had been persistently modest and well below the pace enjoyed by other workers.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At the tipping point of 2015, however, as the labor market continued to strengthen, the trend reversed, with wage growth for the lowest quartile consistently and significantly exceeding that of other workers (figure 4).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At the end of 2015, the Black unemployment rate was still quite elevated, at 9 percent, despite the relatively low overall unemployment rate.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: But that disparity too began to shrink; as the expansion continued beyond 2015, Black unemployment reached a historic low of 5.2 percent, and the gap between Black and white unemployment rates was the narrowest since 1972, when data on unemployment by race started to be collected.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Black unemployment has tended to rise more than overall unemployment in recessions but also to fall more quickly in expansions.4Over the course of a long expansion, these persistent disparities can decline significantly, but, without policies to address their underlying causes, they may increase again when the economy ultimately turns down.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: These late-breaking improvements in the labor market did not result in unwanted upward pressures on inflation, as might have been expected; in fact, inflation did not even rise to 2 percent on a sustained basis.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: There was every reason to expect that the labor market could have strengthened even further without causing a worrisome increase in inflation were it not for the onset of the pandemic.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The Labor Market TodayThe state of our labor market today could hardly be more different.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Despite the surprising speed of recovery early on, we are still very far from a strong labor market whose benefits are broadly shared.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Employment in January of this year was nearly 10 million below its February 2020 level, a greater shortfall than the worst of the Great Recession's aftermath (figure 5).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: After rising to 14.8 percent in April of last year, the published unemployment rate has fallen relatively swiftly, reaching 6.3 percent in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: But published unemployment rates during COVID have dramatically understated the deterioration in the labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Most importantly, the pandemic has led to the largest 12-month decline in labor force participation since at least 1948.5Fear of the virus and the disappearance of employment opportunities in the sectors most affected by it, such as restaurants, hotels, and entertainment venues, have led many to withdraw from the workforce.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At the same time, virtual schooling has forced many parents to leave the work force to provide all-day care for their children.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: All told, nearly 5 million people say the pandemic prevented them from looking for work in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In addition, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that many unemployed individuals have been misclassified as employed.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Correcting this misclassification and counting those who have left the labor force since last February as unemployed would boost the unemployment rate to close to 10 percent in January (figure 6).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Unfortunately, even those grim statistics understate the decline in labor market conditions for the most economically vulnerable Americans.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Aggregate employment has declined 6.5 percent since last February, but the decline in employment for workers in the top quartile of the wage distribution has been only 4 percent, while the decline for the bottom quartile has been a staggering 17 percent (figure 7).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Moreover, employment for these workers has changed little in recent months, while employment for the higher-wage groups has continued to improve.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Similarly, the unemployment rates for Blacks and Hispanics have risen significantly more than for whites since February 2020 (figure 8).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: As a result, economic disparities that were already too wide have widened further.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In the past few months, improvement in labor market conditions stalled as the rate of infections sharply increased.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In particular, jobs in the leisure and hospitality sector dropped over 1/2 million in December and a further 61,000 in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The recovery continues to depend on controlling the spread of the virus, which will require mass vaccinations in addition to continued vigilance in social distancing and mask wearing in the meantime.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Since the onset of the pandemic, we have been concerned about its longer-term effects on the labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Extended periods of unemployment can inflict persistent damage on lives and livelihoods while also eroding the productive capacity of the economy.6And we know from the previous expansion that it can take many years to reverse the damage.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: At the start of the pandemic, the increase in unemployment was almost entirely due to temporary job losses.7Temporarily laid-off workers tend to return to work much more quickly, on average, than those whose ties to their former employers are permanently severed.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: But as some sectors of the economy have continued to struggle, permanent job loss has increased (figure 9).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: So too has long-term unemployment.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Still, as of January, the level of permanent job loss, as a fraction of the labor force, was considerably smaller than during the Great Recession.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Research shows that the Paycheck Protection Program has played an important role in limiting permanent layoffs and preserving small businesses.8The renewal of the program this year in the face of another surge in COVID-related job cuts is an encouraging development.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Of course, in a healthy market-based economy, perpetual churn will always render some jobs obsolete as they are replaced by new employment opportunities.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Over time, workers and capital move from firm to firm and from sector to sector.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: It is likely that the pandemic has both increased the need for such movements and brought forward some movement that would have occurred eventually.9

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Getting Back to a Strong Labor MarketSo how do we get from where we are today back to a strong labor market that benefits all Americans and that starts to heal the damage already done?

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: And what can we do to sustain those benefits over time?

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Experience tells us that getting to and staying at full employment will not be easy.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In the near term, policies that bring the pandemic to an end as soon as possible are paramount.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In addition, workers and households who struggle to find their place in the post-pandemic economy are likely to need continued support.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The same is true for many small businesses that are likely to prosper again once the pandemic is behind us.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Also important is a patiently accommodative monetary policy stance that embraces the lessons of the past—about the labor market in particular and the economy more generally.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: I described several of those important lessons, as well as our new policy framework, at the Jackson Hole conference last year.10I have already mentioned the broad-based benefits that a strong labor market can deliver and noted that many of these benefits only arose toward the end of the previous expansion.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: I also noted that these benefits were achieved with low inflation.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Indeed, inflation has been much lower and more stable over the past three decades than in earlier times.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In addition, we have seen that the longer-run potential growth rate of the economy appears to be lower than it once was, in part because of population aging, and that the neutral rate of interest—or the rate consistent with the economy being at full employment with 2 percent inflation—is also much lower than before.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: A low neutral rate means that our policy rate will be constrained more often by the effective lower bound.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: That circumstance can lead to worse economic outcomes—particularly for the most economically vulnerable Americans.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: To take these economic developments into account, we made substantial revisions to our monetary policy framework, as described in the FOMC's Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.11This revised statement shares many features with its predecessor, including our view that longer-run inflation of 2 percent is most consistent with our mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: But it also has some innovations.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The revised statement emphasizes that maximum employment is a broad and inclusive goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: This change reflects our appreciation for the benefits of a strong labor market, particularly for many in low- and moderate-income communities.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Recognizing the economy's ability to sustain a robust job market without causing an unwanted increase in inflation, the statement says that our policy decisions will be informed by our "assessments of theshortfallsof employment from its maximum level" rather than by "deviationsfrom its maximum level.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: "12This means that we will not tighten monetary policy solely in response to a strong labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Finally, to counter the adverse economic dynamics that could ensue from declines in inflation expectations in an environment where our main policy tool is more frequently constrained, we now explicitly seek to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: This means that following periods when inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time in the service of keeping inflation expectations well anchored at our 2 percent longer-run goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Our January postmeeting statement on monetary policy implements this new framework.13In particular, we expect that it will be appropriate to maintain the current accommodative target range of the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: In addition, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities by $80 billion and $40 billion per month, respectively, until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The Broad Responsibility for Achieving Maximum EmploymentSeventy-five years ago, in the wake of WWII, the United States faced the challenge of reemploying millions amid a major restructuring of the economy toward peacetime ends.14Part of Congress's response was the Employment Act of 1946, which states that "it is the continuing policy and responsibility of the federal government to use all practicable means .

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: "15As later amended in the Humphrey-Hawkins Act, this provision formed the basis of the employment side of the Fed's dual mandate.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: My colleagues and I are strongly committed to doing all we can to promote this employment goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Given the number of people who have lost their jobs and the likelihood that some will struggle to find work in the post-pandemic economy, achieving and sustaining maximum employment will require more than supportive monetary policy.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: It will require a society-wide commitment, with contributions from across government and the private sector.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: The potential benefits of investing in our nation's workforce are immense.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: Steady employment provides more than a regular paycheck.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
text: It also bestows a sense of purpose, improves mental health, increases lifespans, and benefits workers and their families.16I am confident that with our collective efforts across the government and the private sector, our nation will make sustained progress toward our national goal of maximum employment.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Today I will offer a progress report on the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) efforts to restore price stability to the U.S. economy for the benefit of the American people.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The report must begin by acknowledging the reality that inflation remains far too high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation is imposing significant hardship, straining budgets and shrinking what paychecks will buy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: This is especially painful for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: We currently estimate that 12-month personal consumption expenditures (PCE) inflation through October ran at 6.0 percent (figure 1).1While October inflation data received so far showed a welcome surprise to the downside, these are a single month's data, which followed upside surprises over the previous two months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: As figure 1 makes clear, down months in the data have often been followed by renewed increases.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: It will take substantially more evidence to give comfort that inflation is actually declining.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: By any standard, inflation remains much too high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: For purposes of this discussion, I will focus my comments on core PCE inflation, which omits the food and energy inflation components, which have been lower recently but are quite volatile.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Our inflation goal is for total inflation, of course, as food and energy prices matter a great deal for household budgets.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But core inflation often gives a more accurate indicator of where overall inflation is headed.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Twelve-month core PCE inflation stands at 5.0 percent in our October estimate, approximately where it stood last December when policy tightening was in its early stages.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Over 2022, core inflation rose a few tenths above 5 percent and fell a few tenths below, but it mainly moved sideways.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: So when will inflation come down?

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: I could answer this question by pointing to the inflation forecasts of private-sector forecasters or of FOMC participants, which broadly show a significant decline over the next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But forecasts have been predicting just such a decline for more than a year, while inflation has moved stubbornly sideways.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The truth is that the path ahead for inflation remains highly uncertain.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: For now, let's put aside the forecasts and look instead to the macroeconomic conditions we think we need to see to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: For starters, we need to raise interest rates to a level that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: There is considerable uncertainty about what rate will be sufficient, although there is no doubt that we have made substantial progress, raising our target range for the federal funds rate by 3.75 percentage points since March.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: As our last postmeeting statement indicates, we anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: It seems to me likely that the ultimate level of rates will need to be somewhat higher than thought at the time of the September meeting and Summary of Economic Projections.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: I will return to policy at the end of my comments, but for now, I will simply say that we have more ground to cover.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: We are tightening the stance of policy in order to slow growth in aggregate demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Slowing demand growth should allow supply to catch up with demand and restore the balance that will yield stable prices over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Restoring that balance is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Last year, the ongoing reopening of the economy boosted real gross domestic product (GDP) growth to a very strong 5.7 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: This year, GDP was roughly flat through the first three quarters, and indicators point to modest growth this quarter, which seems likely to bring the year in with very modest growth overall.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Several factors contributed to this slowing growth, including the waning effects of reopening and of pandemic fiscal support, the global implications of Russia's war against Ukraine, and our policy actions, which tightened financial conditions and are affecting economic activity, particularly in interest-sensitive sectors such as housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: We can say that demand growth has slowed, and we expect that this growth will need to remain at a slower pace for a sustained period.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Despite the tighter policy and slower growth over the past year, we have not seen clear progress on slowing inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: To assess what it will take to get inflation down, it is useful to break core inflation into three component categories: core goods inflation, housing services inflation, and inflation in core services other than housing (figure 2).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Core goods inflation has moved down from very high levels over the course of 2022, while housing services inflation has risen rapidly.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Inflation in core services ex housing has fluctuated but shown no clear trend.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: I will discuss each of these items in turn.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Early in the pandemic, goods prices began rising rapidly, as abnormally strong demand was met by pandemic-hampered supply.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Reports from businesses and many indicators suggest that supply chain issues are now easing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Both fuel and nonfuel import prices have fallen in recent months, and indicators of prices paid by manufacturers have moved down.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: While 12-month core goods inflation remains elevated at 4.6 percent, it has fallen nearly 3 percentage points from earlier in the year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: It is far too early to declare goods inflation vanquished, but if current trends continue, goods prices should begin to exert downward pressure on overall inflation in coming months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Housing services inflation measures the rise in the price of all rents and the rise in the rental-equivalent cost of owner-occupied housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Unlike goods inflation, housing services inflation has continued to rise and now stands at 7.1 percent over the past 12 months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Housing inflation tends to lag other prices around inflation turning points, however, because of the slow rate at which the stock of rental leases turns over.2The market rate on new leases is a timelier indicator of where overall housing inflation will go over the next year or so.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Measures of 12-month inflation in new leases rose to nearly 20 percent during the pandemic but have been falling sharply since about midyear (figure 3).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: As figure 3 shows, however, overall housing services inflation has continued to rise as existing leases turn over and jump in price to catch up with the higher level of rents for new leases.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: This is likely to continue well into next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But as long as new lease inflation keeps falling, we would expect housing services inflation to begin falling sometime next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Indeed, a decline in this inflation underlies most forecasts of declining inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Finally, we come to core services other than housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: This spending category covers a wide range of services from health care and education to haircuts and hospitality.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: This is the largest of our three categories, constituting more than half of the core PCE index.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Thus, this may be the most important category for understanding the future evolution of core inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Because wages make up the largest cost in delivering these services, the labor market holds the key to understanding inflation in this category.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: In the labor market, demand for workers far exceeds the supply of available workers, and nominal wages have been growing at a pace well above what would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.3Thus, another condition we are looking for is the restoration of balance between supply and demand in the labor market.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Signs of elevated labor market tightness emerged suddenly in mid-2021.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The unemployment rate at the time was much higher than the 3.5 percent that had prevailed without major signs of tightness before the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Employment was still millions below its level on the eve of the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Looking back, we can see that a significant and persistent labor supply shortfall opened up during the pandemic—a shortfall that appears unlikely to fully close anytime soon.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Comparing the current labor force with the Congressional Budget Office's pre-pandemic forecast of labor force growth reveals a current labor force shortfall of roughly 3-1/2 million people (figure 4, left panel).4This shortfall reflects both lower-than-expected population growth and a lower labor force participation rate (figure 4, right panel).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Participation dropped sharply at the onset of the pandemic because of many factors, including sickness, caregiving, and fear of infection.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Many forecasters expected that participation would move back up fairly quickly as the pandemic faded.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: And for workers in their prime working years, it mostly has.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Overall participation, however, remains well below pre-pandemic trends.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Some of the participation gap reflects workers who are still out of the labor force because they are sick with COVID-19 or continue to suffer lingering symptoms from previous COVID infections ("long COVID").5But recent research by Fed economists finds that the participation gap is now mostly due to excess retirements—that is, retirements in excess of what would have been expected from population aging alone.6These excess retirements might now account for more than 2 million of the 3‑1/2 million shortfall in the labor force.7

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: What explains these excess retirements?

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Health issues have surely played a role, as COVID has posed a particularly large threat to the lives and health of the elderly.8In addition, many older workers lost their jobs in the early stages of the pandemic, when layoffs were historically high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The cost of finding new employment may have appeared particularly large for these workers, given pandemic-related disruptions to the work environment and health concerns.9Also, gains in the stock market and rising house prices in the first two years of the pandemic contributed to an increase in wealth that likely facilitated early retirement for some people.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The data so far do not suggest that excess retirements are likely to unwind because of retirees returning to the labor force.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Older workers are still retiring at higher rates, and retirees do not appear to be returning to the labor force in sufficient numbers to meaningfully reduce the total number of excess retirees.10

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The second factor contributing to the labor supply shortfall is slower growth in the working-age population.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The combination of a plunge in net immigration and a surge in deaths during the pandemic probably accounts for about 1-1/2 million missing workers.11

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Policies to support labor supply are not the domain of the Fed: Our tools work principally on demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Without advocating any particular policy, however, I will say that policies to support labor force participation could, over time, bring benefits to the workers who join the labor force and support overall economic growth.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Such policies would take time to implement and have their effects, however.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: For the near term, a moderation of labor demand growth will be required to restore balance to the labor market.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Currently, the unemployment rate is at 3.7 percent, near 50-year lows, and job openings exceed available workers by about 4 million—that is about 1.7 job openings for every person looking for work (figure 5).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: So far, we have seen only tentative signs of moderation of labor demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: With slower GDP growth this year, job gains have stepped down from more than 450,000 per month over the first seven months of the year to about 290,000 per month over the past three months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But this job growth remains far in excess of the pace needed to accommodate population growth over time—about 100,000 per month by many estimates.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Job openings have fallen by about 1.5 million this year but remain higher than at any time before the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Wage growth, too, shows only tentative signs of returning to balance.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Some measures of wage growth have ticked down recently (figure 6).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But the declines are very modest so far relative to earlier increases and still leave wage growth well above levels consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: To be clear, strong wage growth is a good thing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: But for wage growth to be sustainable, it needs to be consistent with 2 percent inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Let's sum up this review of economic conditions that we think we need to see to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Growth in economic activity has slowed to well below its longer-run trend, and this needs to be sustained.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Bottlenecks in goods production are easing and goods price inflation appears to be easing as well, and this, too, must continue.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Housing services inflation will probably keep rising well into next year, but if inflation on new leases continues to fall, we will likely see housing services inflation begin to fall later next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Finally, the labor market, which is especially important for inflation in core services ex housing, shows only tentative signs of rebalancing, and wage growth remains well above levels that would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Despite some promising developments, we have a long way to go in restoring price stability.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Returning to monetary policy, my FOMC colleagues and I are strongly committed to restoring price stability.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: After our November meeting, we noted that we anticipated that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate in order to attain a policy stance that is sufficiently restrictive to move inflation down to 2 percent over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Monetary policy affects the economy and inflation with uncertain lags, and the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Thus, it makes sense to moderate the pace of our rate increases as we approach the level of restraint that will be sufficient to bring inflation down.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: The time for moderating the pace of rate increases may come as soon as the December meeting.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: Given our progress in tightening policy, the timing of that moderation is far less significant than the questions of how much further we will need to raise rates to control inflation, and the length of time it will be necessary to hold policy at a restrictive level.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: It is likely that restoring price stability will require holding policy at a restrictive level for some time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: History cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
text: We will stay the course until the job is done.
