title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: At past Jackson Hole conferences, I have discussed broad topics such as the ever-changing structure of the economy and the challenges of conducting monetary policy under high uncertainty.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Today, my remarks will be shorter, my focus narrower, and my message more direct.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) overarching focus right now is to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The burdens of high inflation fall heaviest on those who are least able to bear them.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Restoring price stability will take some time and requires using our tools forcefully to bring demand and supply into better balance.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Reducing inflation is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Moreover, there will very likely be some softening of labor market conditions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: While higher interest rates, slower growth, and softer labor market conditions will bring down inflation, they will also bring some pain to households and businesses.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: These are the unfortunate costs of reducing inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: But a failure to restore price stability would mean far greater pain.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The U.S. economy is clearly slowing from the historically high growth rates of 2021, which reflected the reopening of the economy following the pandemic recession.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: While the latest economic data have been mixed, in my view our economy continues to show strong underlying momentum.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The labor market is particularly strong, but it is clearly out of balance, with demand for workers substantially exceeding the supply of available workers.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Inflation is running well above 2 percent, and high inflation has continued to spread through the economy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: While the lower inflation readings for July are welcome, a single month's improvement falls far short of what the Committee will need to see before we are confident that inflation is moving down.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: We are moving our policy stance purposefully to a level that will be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: At our most recent meeting in July, the FOMC raised the target range for the federal funds rate to 2.25 to 2.5 percent, which is in the Summary of Economic Projection's (SEP) range of estimates of where the federal funds rate is projected to settle in the longer run.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: In current circumstances, with inflation running far above 2 percent and the labor market extremely tight, estimates of longer-run neutral are not a place to stop or pause.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: July's increase in the target range was the second 75 basis point increase in as many meetings, and I said then that another unusually large increase could be appropriate at our next meeting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: We are now about halfway through the intermeeting period.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Our decision at the September meeting will depend on the totality of the incoming data and the evolving outlook.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: At some point, as the stance of monetary policy tightens further, it likely will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Restoring price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive policy stance for some time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Committee participants' most recent individual projections from the June SEP showed the median federal funds rate running slightly below 4 percent through the end of 2023.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Participants will update their projections at the September meeting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Our monetary policy deliberations and decisions build on what we have learned about inflation dynamics both from the high and volatile inflation of the 1970s and 1980s, and from the low and stable inflation of the past quarter-century.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: In particular, we are drawing on three important lessons.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The first lesson is that central bankscanandshouldtake responsibility for delivering low and stable inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: It may seem strange now that central bankers and others once needed convincing on these two fronts, but as former Chairman Ben Bernanke has shown, both propositions were widely questioned during the Great Inflation period.1Today, we regard these questions as settled.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Our responsibility to deliver price stability is unconditional.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: It is true that the current high inflation is a global phenomenon, and that many economies around the world face inflation as high or higher than seen here in the United States.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: It is also true, in my view, that the current high inflation in the United States is the product of strong demand and constrained supply, and that the Fed's tools work principally on aggregate demand.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: None of this diminishes the Federal Reserve's responsibility to carry out our assigned task of achieving price stability.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: There is clearly a job to do in moderating demand to better align with supply.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: We are committed to doing that job.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The second lesson is that the public's expectations about future inflation can play an important role in setting the path of inflation over time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Today, by many measures, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: That is broadly true of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, and of market-based measures as well.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: But that is not grounds for complacency, with inflation having run well above our goal for some time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: If the public expects that inflation will remain low and stable over time, then, absent major shocks, it likely will.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Unfortunately, the same is true of expectations of high and volatile inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: During the 1970s, as inflation climbed, the anticipation of high inflation became entrenched in the economic decisionmaking of households and businesses.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The more inflation rose, the more people came to expect it to remain high, and they built that belief into wage and pricing decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: As former Chairman Paul Volcker put it at the height of the Great Inflation in 1979, "Inflation feeds in part on itself, so part of the job of returning to a more stable and more productive economy must be to break the grip of inflationary expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: One useful insight into how actual inflation may affect expectations about its future path is based in the concept of "rational inattention.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: "3When inflation is persistently high, households and businesses must pay close attention and incorporate inflation into their economic decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: When inflation is low and stable, they are freer to focus their attention elsewhere.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Former Chairman Alan Greenspan put it this way: "For all practical purposes, price stability means that expected changes in the average price level are small enough and gradual enough that they do not materially enter business and household financial decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Of course, inflation has just about everyone's attention right now, which highlights a particular risk today: The longer the current bout of high inflation continues, the greater the chance that expectations of higher inflation will become entrenched.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: That brings me to the third lesson, which is that we must keep at it until the job is done.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: History shows that the employment costs of bringing down inflation are likely to increase with delay, as high inflation becomes more entrenched in wage and price setting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: The successful Volcker disinflation in the early 1980s followed multiple failed attempts to lower inflation over the previous 15 years.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: A lengthy period of very restrictive monetary policy was ultimately needed to stem the high inflation and start the process of getting inflation down to the low and stable levels that were the norm until the spring of last year.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: Our aim is to avoid that outcome by acting with resolve now.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: These lessons are guiding us as we use our tools to bring inflation down.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: We are taking forceful and rapid steps to moderate demand so that it comes into better alignment with supply, and to keep inflation expectations anchored.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
text: We will keep at it until we are confident the job is done.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak with you today.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Let me first pause to recognize the millions who are suffering the tragic consequences of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: At the Federal Reserve, our monetary policy is guided by the dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: From that standpoint, the current picture is plain to see: The labor market is very strong, and inflation is much too high.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship, especially on those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: There is an obvious need to move expeditiously to return the stance of monetary policy to a more neutral level, and then to move to more restrictive levels if that is what is required to restore price stability.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We are committed to restoring price stability while preserving a strong labor market.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: At our meeting that concluded last week, we took several steps in pursuit of these goals: We raised our policy interest rate for the first time since the start of the pandemic and said that we anticipate that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate to reach our objectives.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We also said that we expect to begin reducing the size of our balance sheet at a coming meeting.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In my press conference, I noted that action could come as soon as our next meeting in May, though that is not a decision that we have made.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: These actions, along with the adjustments we have made since last fall, represent a substantial firming in the stance of policy with the intention of restoring price stability.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In my comments today, I will first discuss the economic conditions that warrant these actions and then address the path ahead for monetary policy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The Labor Market Is Very Strong and Extremely TightTo begin with employment, in the last few years of the historically long expansion that ended with the arrival of the pandemic, we saw the remarkable benefits of an extended period of strong labor market conditions.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We seek to foster another long expansion in order to realize those benefits again.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The labor market has substantial momentum.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Employment growth powered through the difficult Omicron wave, adding 1.75 million jobs over the past three months.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The unemployment rate has fallen to 3.8 percent, near historical lows, and has reached this level much faster than anticipated by most forecasters (figure 1).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: While disparities in employment remain, job growth has been widespread across racial, ethnic, and demographic groups.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: By many measures, the labor market is extremely tight, significantly tighter than the very strong job market just before the pandemic.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: There are far more job openings going unfilled today than before the pandemic, despite today's unemployment rate being higher.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Indeed, there are a record 1.7 posted job openings for each person who is looking for work.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Record numbers of people are quitting jobs each month, typically to take another job with higher pay.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: And nominal wages are rising at the fastest pace in decades, with the gains strongest for those at the lower end of the wage distribution and among production and nonsupervisory workers (figure 2).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: It is worth considering why the labor market is so tight, given that the unemployment rate is actually higher than it was before the pandemic.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: One explanation is that the natural rate of unemployment may be temporarily elevated, so wage pressure is greater for any given level of unemployment.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The sheer volume of hiring may have taxed the capacity of the market to bring workers and jobs together.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The Delta and Omicron variants complicated hiring, and the strong financial position of households may have allowed some to be more selective in their job search.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Over time, we might expect these factors to fade, reducing pressure in the job market.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: A second source of labor market tightness is that the labor force participation rate dropped sharply in the pandemic and has only partly recovered.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: As a result, the labor force remains below its pre-pandemic trend (figure 3).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Total demand for labor, measured by total employment plus posted job openings, has substantially recovered and far exceeds the size of the workforce.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: About half of the shortfall in labor force participation is attributable to retirements during the pandemic.1History suggests that most of those retirees are unlikely to reenter the workforce.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: But some nonparticipation is due to factors that may fade with time, such as caregiving needs and fear of contracting COVID-19.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: With prime-aged participation still well below its pre-pandemic level, there is room for further progress.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: A more complete rebound is, however, likely to take some time.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Increases in labor force participation often substantially lag declines in unemployment.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Overall, the labor market is strong but showing a clear imbalance of supply and demand.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Our monetary policy tools cannot help with labor supply in the near term, but in a long expansion, the factors holding back supply will likely ease.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In the meantime, we aim to use our tools to moderate demand growth, thereby facilitating continued, sustainable increases in employment and wages.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The Inflation Outlook Has Deteriorated SignificantlyTurning to price stability, the inflation outlook had deteriorated significantly this year even before Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The rise in inflation has been much greater and more persistent than forecasters generally expected.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: For example, at the time of our June 2021 meeting, every Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participant and all but one of 35 submissions in the Survey of Professional Forecasters predicted that 2021 inflation would be below 4 percent.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Inflation came in at 5.5 percent.2

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: For a time, moderate inflation forecasts looked plausible—the one-month headline and core inflation rates declined steadily from April through September.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: But inflation moved up sharply in the fall, and, just since our December meeting, the median FOMC projection for year-end 2022 jumped from 2.6 percent to 4.3 percent.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Why have forecasts been so far off?

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In my view, an important part of the explanation is that forecasters widely underestimated the severity and persistence of supply-side frictions, which, when combined with strong demand, especially for durable goods, produced surprisingly high inflation.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The pandemic and the associated shutdown and reopening of the economy caused a serious upheaval in many parts of the economy, snarling supply chains, constraining labor supply, and creating a major boom in demand for goods and a bust in services demand.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The combination of the surge in goods demand with supply chain bottlenecks led to sharply rising goods prices (figure 4).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The most notable example here is motor vehicles.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Prices soared across the vehicles sector as booming demand was met by a sharpdeclinein global production during the summer of 2021, owing to shortages of computer chips.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Production remains below pre-pandemic levels, and an expected sharp decline in prices has been repeatedly postponed.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Many forecasters, including FOMC participants, had been expecting inflation to cool in the second half of last year, as the economy started going back to normal after vaccines became widely available.3Expectations were that the supply-side damage would begin to heal.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Schools would reopen—freeing parents to return to work—and labor supply would begin bouncing back, kinks in supply chains would begin resolving, and consumption would start rotating back to services, all of which could reduce price pressures.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: While schools are open, none of the other expectations has been fully met.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Part of the reason may be that, contrary to expectations, COVID has not gone away with the arrival of vaccines.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In fact, we are now headed once again into more COVID-related supply disruptions from China.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: It continues to seem likely that hoped-for supply-side healing will come over time as the world ultimately settles into some new normal, but the timing and scope of that relief are highly uncertain.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In the meantime, as we set policy, we will be looking to actual progress on these issues and not assuming significant near-term supply-side relief.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The Policy ResponseAs the magnitude and persistence of the increase in inflation became increasingly clear over the second half of last year, and as the job market recovery accelerated beyond expectations, the FOMC pivoted to progressively less accommodative monetary policy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In June, the median FOMC participant projected that the federal funds rate would remain at its effective lower bound through the end of 2022, and as the news came in, the projected policy paths shifted higher (figure 5).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The median projection that accompanied last week's 25 basis point rate increase shows the federal funds rate at 1.9 percent by the end of this year and rising above its estimated longer-run normal value in 2023.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The latest FOMC statement also indicates that the Committee expects to begin reducing the size of our balance sheet at a coming meeting.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: I believe that these policy actions and those to come will help bring inflation down near 2 percent over the next 3 years.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: As always, our policy projections are not a Committee decision or fixed plan.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Instead, they are a summary of what the FOMC participants see as the most likely case going forward.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The events of the past four weeks remind us that, in tumultuous times, what seems like the most likely scenario may change quite quickly: Each Summary of Economic Projections reflects a point in time and can become outdated quickly at times like these, when events are developing rapidly.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Thus, my main message today is that, as the outlook evolves, we will adjust policy as needed in order to ensure a return to price stability with a strong job market.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Let me now turn to three questions about the likely evolution of policy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: How will fallout from the invasion of Ukraine affect the economy and monetary policy?Russia's invasion of Ukraine may have significant effects on the world economy and the U.S. economy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The magnitude and persistence of these effects remain highly uncertain and depend on events yet to come.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Russia is one of the world's largest producers of commodities, and Ukraine is a key producer of several commodities as well, including wheat and neon, which is used in the production of computer chips.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: There is no recent experience with significant market disruption across such a broad range of commodities.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In addition to the direct effects from higher global oil and commodity prices, the invasion and related events are likely to restrain economic activity abroad and further disrupt supply chains, which would create spillovers to the U.S. economy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We might look to the historical experience with oil price shocks in the 1970s—not a happy story.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Fortunately, the United States is now much better situated to weather oil price shocks.4We are now the world's largest producer of oil, and our economy is significantly less oil intensive than in the 1970s.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Today a rise in oil prices has mixed effects on the economy, lowering real household incomes and thus demand, but raising investment in drilling over time and benefiting oil-producing areas more generally.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: On net, oil shocks tend to weigh on output in the U.S. economy, but by far less than in the 1970s.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Second, how likely is it that monetary policy can lower inflation without causing a recession?Our goal is to restore price stability while fostering another long expansion and sustaining a strong labor market.In the FOMC participant projections I just described, the economy achieves a soft landing, with inflation coming down and unemployment holding steady.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Growth slows as the very fast growth from the early stages of reopening fades, the effects of fiscal support wane, and monetary policy accommodation is removed.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Some have argued that history stacks the odds against achieving a soft landing, and point to the 1994 episode as the only successful soft landing in the postwar period.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: I believe that the historical record provides some grounds for optimism: Soft, or at least soft-ish, landings have been relatively common in U.S. monetary history.5In three episodes—in 1965, 1984, and 1994—the Fed raised the federal funds rate significantly in response to perceived overheating without precipitating a recession (figure 6).6In other cases, recessions chronologically followed the conclusion of a tightening cycle, but the recessions were not apparently due to excessive tightening of monetary policy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: For example, the tightening from 2015 to 2019 was followed by the pandemic-induced recession.7

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: I hasten to add that no one expects that bringing about a soft landing will be straightforward in the current context—very little is straightforward in the current context.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: And monetary policy is often said to be a blunt instrument, not capable of surgical precision.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: My colleagues and I will do our very best to succeed in this challenging task.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: It is worth noting that today the economy is very strong and is well positioned to handle tighter monetary policy.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Finally, what will it take to restore price stability?The ultimate responsibility for price stability rests with the Federal Reserve.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Price stability is essential if we are going to have another sustained period of strong labor market conditions.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: I believe that the policy approach that I have laid out is well suited to achieving this outcome.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We will take the necessary steps to ensure a return to price stability.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In particular, if we conclude that it is appropriate to move more aggressively by raising the federal funds rate by more than 25 basis points at a meeting or meetings, we will do so.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: And if we determine that we need to tighten beyond common measures of neutral and into a more restrictive stance, we will do that as well.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Our monetary policy framework, as embodied in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, emphasizes that having longer-term inflation expectations anchored at our longer-run objective of 2 percent helps us achieve both our dual-mandate objectives.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: While we cannot measure longer-term expectations directly, we monitor a variety of survey- and market-based indicators.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In the recent period, short-term inflation expectations have, of course, risen with inflation, but longer-run expectations remain well anchored in their historical ranges (figure 7).

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: The added near-term upward pressure from the invasion of Ukraine on inflation from energy, food, and other commodities comes at a time of already too high inflation.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: In normal times, when employment and inflation are close to our objectives, monetary policy would look through a brief burst of inflation associated with commodity price shocks.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: However, the risk is rising that an extended period of high inflation could push longer-term expectations uncomfortably higher, which underscores the need for the Committee to move expeditiously as I have described.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: ConclusionThe past two years have been extraordinarily challenging for many Americans.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Two years ago, more than 20 million people were losing their jobs, millions were falling ill, and lives were being disrupted.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We have made enormous strides since then.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Today, as I have discussed, the labor market is very strong.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: But, to end where I began, inflation is much too high.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: We have the necessary tools, and we will use them to restore price stability.

title: Restoring Price Stability
text: Note:On April 7, 2022, the legend for Figure 3 was corrected to "CPS employment plus job openings."

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: At last year's Jackson Hole symposium, I delivered a brief, direct message.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: My remarks this year will be a bit longer, but the message is the same: It is the Fed's job to bring inflation down to our 2 percent goal, and we will do so.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We have tightened policy significantly over the past year.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Although inflation has moved down from its peak—a welcome development—it remains too high.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We are prepared to raise rates further if appropriate, and intend to hold policy at a restrictive level until we are confident that inflation is moving sustainably down toward our objective.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Today I will review our progress so far and discuss the outlook and the uncertainties we face as we pursue our dual mandate goals.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: I will conclude with a summary of what this means for policy.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Given how far we have come, at upcoming meetings we are in a position to proceed carefully as we assess the incoming data and the evolving outlook and risks.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The Decline in Inflation So FarThe ongoing episode of high inflation initially emerged from a collision between very strong demand and pandemic-constrained supply.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: By the time the Federal Open Market Committee raised the policy rate in March 2022, it was clear that bringing down inflation would depend on both the unwinding of the unprecedented pandemic-related demand and supply distortions and on our tightening of monetary policy, which would slow the growth of aggregate demand, allowing supply time to catch up.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: While these two forces are now working together to bring down inflation, the process still has a long way to go, even with the more favorable recent readings.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: On a 12-month basis, U.S. total, or "headline," PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation peaked at 7 percent in June 2022 and declined to 3.3 percent as of July, following a trajectory roughly in line with global trends (figure 1, panel A).1The effects of Russia's war against Ukraine have been a primary driver of the changes in headline inflation around the world since early 2022.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Headline inflation is what households and businesses experience most directly, so this decline is very good news.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: But food and energy prices are influenced by global factors that remain volatile, and can provide a misleading signal of where inflation is headed.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: In my remaining comments, I will focus on core PCE inflation, which omits the food and energy components.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: On a 12-month basis, core PCE inflation peaked at 5.4 percent in February 2022 and declined gradually to 4.3 percent in July (figure 1, panel B).

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The lower monthly readings for core inflation in June and July were welcome, but two months of good data are only the beginning of what it will take to build confidence that inflation is moving down sustainably toward our goal.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We can't yet know the extent to which these lower readings will continue or where underlying inflation will settle over coming quarters.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Twelve-month core inflation is still elevated, and there is substantial further ground to cover to get back to price stability.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: To understand the factors that will likely drive further progress, it is useful to separately examine the three broad components of core PCE inflation—inflation for goods, for housing services, and for all other services, sometimes referred to as nonhousing services (figure 2).

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Core goods inflation has fallen sharply, particularly for durable goods, as both tighter monetary policy and the slow unwinding of supply and demand dislocations are bringing it down.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The motor vehicle sector provides a good illustration.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Earlier in the pandemic, demand for vehicles rose sharply, supported by low interest rates, fiscal transfers, curtailed spending on in-person services, and shifts in preference away from using public transportation and from living in cities.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: But because of a shortage of semiconductors, vehicle supply actually fell.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Vehicle prices spiked, and a large pool of pent-up demand emerged.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: As the pandemic and its effects have waned, production and inventories have grown, and supply has improved.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: At the same time, higher interest rates have weighed on demand.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Interest rates on auto loans have nearly doubled since early last year, and customers report feeling the effect of higher rates on affordability.2On net, motor vehicle inflation has declined sharply because of the combined effects of these supply and demand factors.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Similar dynamics are playing out for core goods inflation overall.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: As they do, the effects of monetary restraint should show through more fully over time.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Core goods prices fell the past two months, but on a 12-month basis, core goods inflation remains well above its pre-pandemic level.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Sustained progress is needed, and restrictive monetary policy is called for to achieve that progress.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: In the highly interest-sensitive housing sector, the effects of monetary policy became apparent soon after liftoff.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Mortgage rates doubled over the course of 2022, causing housing starts and sales to fall and house price growth to plummet.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Growth in market rents soon peaked and then steadily declined (figure 3).3

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Measured housing services inflation lagged these changes, as is typical, but has recently begun to fall.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: This inflation metric reflects rents paid by all tenants, as well as estimates of the equivalent rents that could be earned from homes that are owner occupied.4Because leases turn over slowly, it takes time for a decline in market rent growth to work its way into the overall inflation measure.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The market rent slowdown has only recently begun to show through to that measure.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The slowing growth in rents for new leases over roughly the past year can be thought of as "in the pipeline" and will affect measured housing services inflation over the coming year.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Going forward, if market rent growth settles near pre-pandemic levels, housing services inflation should decline toward its pre-pandemic level as well.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We will continue to watch the market rent data closely for a signal of the upside and downside risks to housing services inflation.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The final category, nonhousing services, accounts for over half of the core PCE index and includes a broad range of services, such as health care, food services, transportation, and accommodations.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Twelve-month inflation in this sector has moved sideways since liftoff.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Inflation measured over the past three and six months has declined, however, which is encouraging.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Part of the reason for the modest decline of nonhousing services inflation so far is that many of these services were less affected by global supply chain bottlenecks and are generally thought to be less interest sensitive than other sectors such as housing or durable goods.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Production of these services is also relatively labor intensive, and the labor market remains tight.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Given the size of this sector, some further progress here will be essential to restoring price stability.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Over time, restrictive monetary policy will help bring aggregate supply and demand back into better balance, reducing inflationary pressures in this key sector.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The OutlookTurning to the outlook, although further unwinding of pandemic-related distortions should continue to put some downward pressure on inflation, restrictive monetary policy will likely play an increasingly important role.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Getting inflation sustainably back down to 2 percent is expected to require a period of below-trend economic growth as well as some softening in labor market conditions.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Economic growthRestrictive monetary policy has tightened financial conditions, supporting the expectation of below-trend growth.5Since last year's symposium, the two-year real yield is up about 250 basis points, and longer-term real yields are higher as well—by nearly 150 basis points.6Beyond changes in interest rates, bank lending standards have tightened, and loan growth has slowed sharply.7Such a tightening of broad financial conditions typically contributes to a slowing in the growth of economic activity, and there is evidence of that in this cycle as well.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: For example, growth in industrial production has slowed, and the amount spent on residential investment has declined in each of the past five quarters (figure 4).

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: But we are attentive to signs that the economy may not be cooling as expected.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: So far this year, GDP (gross domestic product) growth has come in above expectations and above its longer-run trend, and recent readings on consumer spending have been especially robust.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: In addition, after decelerating sharply over the past 18 months, the housing sector is showing signs of picking back up.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Additional evidence of persistently above-trend growth could put further progress on inflation at risk and could warrant further tightening of monetary policy.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The labor marketThe rebalancing of the labor market has continued over the past year but remains incomplete.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Labor supply has improved, driven by stronger participation among workers aged 25 to 54 and by an increase in immigration back toward pre-pandemic levels.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Indeed, the labor force participation rate of women in their prime working years reached an all-time high in June.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Demand for labor has moderated as well.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Job openings remain high but are trending lower.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Payroll job growth has slowed significantly.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Total hours worked has been flat over the past six months, and the average workweek has declined to the lower end of its pre-pandemic range, reflecting a gradual normalization in labor market conditions (figure 5).

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: This rebalancing has eased wage pressures.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Wage growth across a range of measures continues to slow, albeit gradually (figure 6).

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: While nominal wage growth must ultimately slow to a rate that is consistent with 2 percent inflation, what matters for households is real wage growth.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Even as nominal wage growth has slowed, real wage growth has been increasing as inflation has fallen.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We expect this labor market rebalancing to continue.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Evidence that the tightness in the labor market is no longer easing could also call for a monetary policy response.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Uncertainty and Risk Management along the Path ForwardTwo percent is and will remain our inflation target.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We are committed to achieving and sustaining a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to that level over time.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: It is challenging, of course, to know in real time when such a stance has been achieved.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: There are some challenges that are common to all tightening cycles.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: For example, real interest rates are now positive and well above mainstream estimates of the neutral policy rate.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We see the current stance of policy as restrictive, putting downward pressure on economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: But we cannot identify with certainty the neutral rate of interest, and thus there is always uncertainty about the precise level of monetary policy restraint.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: That assessment is further complicated by uncertainty about the duration of the lags with which monetary tightening affects economic activity and especially inflation.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Since the symposium a year ago, the Committee has raised the policy rate by 300 basis points, including 100 basis points over the past seven months.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: And we have substantially reduced the size of our securities holdings.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: The wide range of estimates of these lags suggests that there may be significant further drag in the pipeline.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Beyond these traditional sources of policy uncertainty, the supply and demand dislocations unique to this cycle raise further complications through their effects on inflation and labor market dynamics.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: For example, so far, job openings have declined substantially without increasing unemployment—a highly welcome but historically unusual result that appears to reflect large excess demand for labor.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: In addition, there is evidence that inflation has become more responsive to labor market tightness than was the case in recent decades.8These changing dynamics may or may not persist, and this uncertainty underscores the need for agile policymaking.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: These uncertainties, both old and new, complicate our task of balancing the risk of tightening monetary policy too much against the risk of tightening too little.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Doing too little could allow above-target inflation to become entrenched and ultimately require monetary policy to wring more persistent inflation from the economy at a high cost to employment.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Doing too much could also do unnecessary harm to the economy.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: ConclusionAs is often the case, we are navigating by the stars under cloudy skies.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: In such circumstances, risk-management considerations are critical.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: At upcoming meetings, we will assess our progress based on the totality of the data and the evolving outlook and risks.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Based on this assessment, we will proceed carefully as we decide whether to tighten further or, instead, to hold the policy rate constant and await further data.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: Restoring price stability is essential to achieving both sides of our dual mandate.

title: Inflation:  Progress and the Path Ahead
text: We will need price stability to achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.
